reviewText:
Let's start with the good stuff: Paul Robertson's sprite design is excellent. Much like Scott Pilgrim on the consoles, the character design is pretty sharp, and this is clearly a game he can cut loose on more that he did on Pilgrim. Of course, this also means his creative boxes of body horror and gore get checked more sharply, too.

The main issue is that this is marketed as a Metal Slug-style game, but has none of the speed or energy. Rather than rewarding a run 'n gun style, you often cautiously stop to take down tiresome enemies with shields (their strength is in trying to bore you to death) and their ilk. It honestly reminds me more of the slow pace of early Mega Man games, only without the rad boss fights. The large, sprawling stages force you to grind through tons of enemies, and you better enjoy it, because you're going to be forced to visit each stage over and over and over.

Crafting makes upgrading slow and unsatisfying. Though the gun design system is attractive and interesting at first, it's easy to maximize DPS in most situations with a high-damage, small clip revolver in my experience. Most other upgrade systems are perfunctory, but rely on tiresome grinding to get the correct ingredients.

Boss fights are wearisome due to their implementation, similar to that of console hit Monster Hunter, where you have a limited window of time to defeat a boss, and then for some reason it runs away to another part of the stage, forcing you to grind over to its new location, or tiresomely set up in a new location to just wait for it to reemerge. Add in the fact that the bosses are clearly designed for multiplayer, so a single player has to take longer to beat them... and the stage overall has a time limit, so it's possible to fail the stage if your luck in locating the boss is bad.

It ultimately combines the worst of the old (enemies spawning just off screen, long enemy patterns where you can't hurt foes) and new (repetitive fetch missions through the same area, tiresome crafting and collecting). That isn't to say it doesn't have some old-school charm to it, but you have to be willing to squeeze and squeeze and squeeze to get that little spurt of nostalgia you wanted from this game in the first place.

reviewText:
I like the game but it is kind of a mixed bag.
The story was way better then i expected from a game like this and even if you don’t like it the story sequences are easy to skip. The sprite based graphics are very easy on the eye and the animations look right.

Gameplay wise it may look like metal slug but it reminds me more of the slow and precise nature of the old mega man games. You can’t take a lot of damage so its all about positioning yourself to easily take out enemies.  The locomotion of your character depends on the weight of your equipment, particularly your gun.

The weapon system works like this, when you kill enemies they drop items, you use these items to craft gun parts and assemble these into guns. If you assemble enough parts with the same stats you can use special ammo, like shots that bounces all over the place or homing missiles. All parts fit together, i.e. you can combine a shotgun stock with a sniper receiver. Now all guns you build are not guaranteed to work well, most probably won’t, but finding one that does is very rewarding and easily my favorite part of the game.

The level design is in general pretty decent. You progress in the game by doing missions, but  a lot of missions use the same map. This would not be a problem since there are several kinds of missions and those on the same map are generally different, but crafting gun parts require farming. This can make the repeating levels quite tedious.
(mitigate; proficiency: medicine, slot 1: hoarder, slot 2: lucky penny )

The bosses in the game inhabit specific places on the map and maps generally have multiple of those. Once you find a boss the mechanics of the boss battle itself is quite good. Easily the worst design decision in the entire game is that unless you are really fast some bosses disappear mid boss battle and appear at some other spot. If you are to slow finding this spot they might teleport again just as you get there. This can lead to some frustration.
(mitigate; slot 1:computer, consumable: shock bombs)

The question is whether or not to recommend this game depends on if you like mega man style platforming, farming for materials, experimenting with crafting and can work around a few annoying design decisions. If unsure wait for a sale.

reviewText: Massively recommended for fans of Mega Man and other such games from the 1980s and 1990s.  Decently-paced, however at the same time could do with less completely unguided fetch quests before it is released properly (at time of writing this was purchased on Steam Early Access).  As for the Metal Slug vibe a lot of people got from this game, I personally do not see it, given that Metal Slug games are (for the most part) linear experiences, however Mercenary Kings allows the player to explore the map, not to mention Metal Slug's one hit and you're dead gameplay is not present in Mercenary Kings.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game and I love Paul Robertson's art style but the game itself has a lot of anti-fun aspects about it.  It's a 2D platformer in a run-n-gun style which I tend to love.  Here's where the problems come in:  You do missions most of which are fetch-quest style but locating who you're supposed to find or the items you need is completely ambiguous task and the map isn't much help.  Also there's time pressure and enemies that are purpose-built to slow your progress (like the guys with the shields).  Other than that, why is there a reload mechanic in this game?  Gears of War has it because it's a cover-based TPS where you have down-time while in cover and it fits the game style there.  Lastly, why can I not shoot diagonally?  There are plenty of instances where enemies are placed on diagonals and are attacking me but I can't fire back.\n\nWhat I expected out of the game was something more fast-paced like Contra/Metal Slug style game.  If you want it to be more  adventure" oriented the time-limit is a big roadblock to fun exploration... the game would also need to be less repetitive enemy/level variety as well then.  Like I said
date: I really want to like this game so I hope you can take this review to heart and do your best to bring out the fun in the game before it's too late."

reviewText:
Everything about this game is great, except for map and mission variety.  It's certainly worth about ten dollars for the first 10ish hours of play, but gets way too samey after that.  The developers gave it artificial length by making you play the same map over and over and over and over again, but this mission you kill a real easy boss, the next mission you collect materials, the next mission you kill all of a certain type of mob, etc.

That having been said, the visuals are on-point, the controls feel like an awesomely perfect old school platformer/shooter, and music, while as limited as the map selection, is real good, the characters are cute and funny, and the gun-play is a blast (pun intended).  The crafting got boring fast, though ... I play games like this so blow peoples heads off, not to stand in front of my gun closet choosing which parts to put together for 12 minutes before each mission.

Steam is going to ask me, Do you recommend this game?" and only give me a Yes or No.
Yes

reviewText:
KICKSTARTER GAME

This is a kickstarter game and at the time of writing is not completely finished ( although there is a lot of content already present). It has a very metal slug esque feel in terms of both graphics and gunplay. It does have a very weird control system which takes some getting used to and I would reccomend a controler until they fix the keyboard layout or at least support a mouse.  This game takes the metal slug formula of platforming, crazy bosses and twitchy gunplay and adds customizing guns, collecting items, and quests (which are either fetch quests or go here- kill this quests) to the mix.

While I would normally reccomend buying this game on sale, there are two reasons I will instead reccomend full price:
1) They consistantly add more content as time goes on. This of course lends itself to waitin until the game is actually complete before purchasing but
2) Being a kickstarter, these guys are a small indie (indy? ) studio and as such would benifit more directly for a full price purchase as a larger portion of the sale would actually go to those who directly made the game

VERDICT: BUY IT IF YOU LIKE RPG IN YOUR METAL SLUG. BUY FULL PRICE IF YOU LIKE INDIE GAME STUDIOS. GOOD ENTERTAINMENT VALUE FOR THE PRICE AND MORE CONTENT IS CONSTANTLY ADDED.

reviewText:
I really want to love this game.  I'm a fan of Paul Robertson, action rpgs, and weapon customization.

But the game makes it so hard.  The very core design of the missions is just dull.  Over and over you are given a timer to search a giant maze like map for a randomly placed item or enemy.  Because the maps are large, even if you luck out by heading in the right direction it's still going to take you 5 minutes. If you get unlucky it'll take 15 minutes easily, and if you run out of time or die you have to start over.  It's like they greatly overestimated how much people enjoyed this, because constant navigation is built into things that don't make sense at all.  You spend 10 minutes searching the random boss spawn points to find which one is active, only for the boss to move to another part of the map mid way through the fight.  Now you spend another 2-5 minutes finding the new location, rinse and repeat, and hope you don't run out of time. The game actually expects you to wander through each map a hundred times at 10-20 minutes apiece.

The weapons you construct have no creativity to them and are just not fun to use.  Sure they are creative art-wise, where you can create a toilet gun, but the moment you try to create a shotgun with more than 2 ammo the game cripples the damage so much as to make it useless.  The real potentials for creativity (piercing shotgun?) are completely unavailable, because you are forced to create a 100% sniper rifle to select piercing ammo.  So you are stuck with a few preset weapon paths, creating incrementally damage increasing versions of the same weapon.  The balance of it works against the mission design, because when you are searching aimlessly through a map of endlessly spawning enemies, making it take 3 seconds to dispatch each enemy (from either low damage ouputs or excessive reload times), it just makes the thing a chore.

It's highly unlikely that this will be patched either, the devs seem hung up on this idea of a grinding time sink somehow being fun, as similar things were in scott pilgrim too.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. This comes from the people who made Scott Pilgrim vs. The World: The Game, which I loved and looks like it plays like Contra or Metal Slug, which I also love. Well, the graphics are very aesthetically pleasing in animation and both character and background designs. There are actually a lot of really cool looking enemies. The music is quite well done too. The problem is the gameplay. While watching videos it looks as if the game does everything right but the problem is: the game just isn't that fun. The game wants to be an old school run and gun but there's a lot of backtracking (which is even more annoying since the enemies respawn) and you have to reload every five or so seconds if you are run and gunning. The idea to put in a reload system was dumb but they way they did it (a time sensitive system) was actually kind of cool. Though it getting annoying fast. I found myself avoiding enemies so I didn't have to reload and then was wondering why I was still playing this game after avoiding the main game mechanic (shooting).

reviewText:
As hard as I try to, I don't enjoy playing this game, even remotely. Every mission I attempt feels tedious, slow, and boring, aided mostly by the fact that most every mission is some sort of completely unguided fetch-quest through samey looking environments that are an absolute pain to navigate through.

If the level design weren't enough to dissuade me from continuing, the limited ammuntion and active reload system makes the gunplay feel especially tedious, and just doesn't work well with the Megaman-style shooting/platforming, especially when the use of cover isn't as much of an option as in Gears of War, the game this particular mechanic came from. I can't count the number of deaths I've encountered after missing my target, only to be shot down during the short idle period in which I wait for the active reload to finish (assuming I successfully reload at all).

The inventory/item system was another annoyance for me; switching between items feels clunky and slow in situations where speed is needed, and always feels like more of a hassle than is worth.

As far as the crafting system goes, I honestly can't stand playing the game long enough to gather the items necessary to really try it out, so I don't have much to say regarding that. Perhaps after upgrading my weapons properly, the enemies will feel far less bullet-spongey, and I'll spend much less time standing in one place, jumping, and shooting in mid-air while I wait for an enemy to finally die (supposedly of boredom).

I'm sorry, I want nothing more than to love this game, but this it's an absolute mess. Including modern game mechanics in an old-school platformer/run and gun sounds good on paper, but does little other than clutter the overall design and slow down gameplay. Perhaps if the level/mission design was a little less annoying, it might work.

To take this game from its current state to something I would enjoy would require gutting the vast majority of the superfluous features, completely overhauling the level design, and possibly even overhauling the crafting system, assuming it is as much of a mess as the rest of the game.

I don't really have any faith in the final product, and I kind of wish I had never spent the money.

reviewText:
The team behind Mercenary Kings are sat in that awkward in-between of not having a cult following from simply existing for a long period of time, like Final Fantasy, and not having the excuse of having never developed a game previously. As such, they're neither excused by rabid fanboys nor by simple naivety. In layman's terms; when they dun goof, no one's in their corner.

For example, it's over a year old (two years if you count Early Access) and it's only just been fixed so that it doesn't crash when you talk to an NPC and try online multiplayer. It's a pretty big deal when such a massive component is unavailable.

There are typos and syntax errors abound in the game text, something that should've been easy enough to fix in their numerous patches on PC. I do have to give kudos to Tribute's response to the concerns of the completionist demographic; when a kickstart-exclusive achievement made 100%ing the game impossible, they introduced a secondary method of acquiring it. That's gravy in my books.

The controls feel a bit like a student's final practical. Need to duck? Nope, there's an item by your feet, you're taking that bullet to the face as the collecting animation immobilises you. Nope, there's a ladder a pixel to your right, you're climbing down now. Need to climb down that ladder? Nope, someone put C4 at the top and your backpack is full! You aren't getting down that ladder until someone picks it up or you make room to pick it up yourself.

Furthermore, the game seems to favour the commitment route for control schemes. When you jump, there's very little you can do to influence the path you'll take once you've left the ground. If you're unfortunate enough to try your knife in a pinch, you'll get locked in an uninterruptible cycle if you press it more than once. You'll need to allow plenty of time for the animation lock to finish if you want to so much as turn your character.

The graphics are the same as you find in Scott Pilgrim vs. The World. Same people, y'see. The style's consistent and the animations are gorgeous, but it becomes clear that some of the spritework was drawn before they finalised the character designs. For example, Lawless' hat bears the wrong logo in her comm. portrait, and Ryack's expression is far too serious for his actual disposition.

I cannot fault the music. It takes a lot of cues from the Sonic games on the Sega Mega Drive (Sonic 2, Sonic Spinball). Gives me dem nostalgia feels. One of the bosses even takes a pointer or two from the first Sonic game.

The Steel Soldier, Titan Trooper and their recolours have an annoying habit of not telegraphing where they're jumping, and since you sometimes need to immediately dodge to avoid collision damage, it's a 50/50 chance of rolling in the right direction.

Oh, and all bosses and enemies deal way more damage via contact than by their lasers, rockets, bullets and missiles. It's pretty much Hug The Wall: The Game for boss encounters, and Flee In Terror: The Horror Flick should you come into contact with the wildlife. Because you can be killed by rabbits. Guess you're allergic?

Bosses randomly teleport to other areas of the map for no reason other than to arbitrarily extend gameplay. If it was purely to pressure the player into rushing the fight before he flees, there wouldn't be a time limit on every mission and its grandma.

There are a handful of large maps that get repeatedly used. The enemy placements are (mostly) the exact same between missions. A room or two will open up sometimes, but in the end, you'll have quickly grown tired of the same recycled layouts and textures before you've even beaten the game.

In later missions, some of the poorer design decisions become evident. For example, you'll leave a room and see a manhack to your upper-right. It's a perfect 45 degree angle. It'll automatically start descending diagonally towards you. If you jump to shoot it, it'll either be too close and hit you horizontally, stunning you for a second or two, or it'll be too high and it'll start moving horizontally early in response-- their AI is programmed so that they rarely become completely level with your gun if given the time and space.

Your movement and jump speeds are decided by how encumbered you are; your gun, your knife, your consumables, things like that (your gun weight is negated if you holster it). It's a really neat idea when it's used exclusively for hiding secrets, but it's not. You have to leap defenselessly if you're too heavy, and the game has a nasty habit of placing enemies in the way of the finish line, and usually there's a threat for not finishing the jumping puzzle" all in one go. Sometimes you have to do the entire thing again
date: sometimes it's a pit of spikes you can't get out of easily and will likely die from. The feature's great on paper but difficult to account for in all of their level designs

reviewText:
'You can’t be serious. Okay listen, this is a suicide mission. There are hundreds of enemies, we know nothing about the terrain and only have very limited suppli-…' – 'It’s okay, we’ll send in the KINGS, they can handle everything.' *Insert some dramatic music*________________________________________________________________________________

'Mercenary Kings‘ is an interesting recipe: You take a portion of 'Mega Man‘, add some elements of ‚Monster Hunter‘ and spice it up with a pinch of 'Metal Slug‘ or 'Contra‘. This may sound like a very odd combination and the reviews are quite ambivalent about the qualities of the game but especially in co-op this game is a blast.

The story itself can be told quite fast: The bad guys called „CLAW“ (they have the brilliant slogan „CLAW is law“) kidnapped a famoust scientist and conducted some evil experiments on a solitary island. To end this madness the military sends a super special unit – the KINGS. No, the story won’t win a creativity award, but it’s solid and full of humor. The crazy characters are quite likeable and several conversations are actually interesting and bring in some plot twists. But you can be honest: You won’t play this game for the story…

…you want these guns. And the knifes. And the ammo. All the good stuff. The gameplay can be compared mostly to a mixture of 'Mega Man‘ (jumping and shooting) and 'Monster Hunter‘ (crafting and grinding): First you have your own hub where you are able to buy items, upgrade your equipment and accept the missions. These jobs bring you into larger areas where you have to fullfill goals e.g. killing or capturing a boss, gathering materials or resucing some hostages. So you start running and jumping through the levels, avoiding obstacles on your way (like e.g. lava, needles and other evil stuff). Meanwhile you're shooting at everything that walks in front of your weapon while looking for hidden items and loot.

The level design is well done, the different areas and layouts allow for some nice exploration and the amount of traps and enemy types really brings some nice variety to the quite repetetive goals. Of course: at the end of several mission there's a boss waiting for you and these buddies provide some nice challenging moments. Most of the time simple button mashing ends in an early death and you really have to understand the patterns and to find a good strategy. Though when you’re finally able to defeat that annoying difficult boss (I look at you 'Metal Woof'!) and he drops the material you were looking for – that’s some pretty great feeling.

Talking about materials: On your journey you’ll stumble across many different ingedrients and materials that can be used to craft individual gun parts, knifes and bionic mods. The amount of different parts is tremendous and they can be combined to fit your playstyle, whether you’re the tanky dude with the shotgun or the spray’n run submachine-type. Crafting new guns, mixing the parts and farming for materials is the core element of the game – and it’s very entertaining.

In terms of the visuals and the sounds I have to admit that the design and the style is gorgeous (I’m a huge fan of well done pixel-graphics). The environment and the characters are detailled, the animations are perfectly fluid and the overall picture is simply great. And in addition there is an amazing soundtrack, that features some really catchy tracks.

I could go on talking about even more positive points, like the splitscreen multiplayer, the co-op mode or the omnipresent humor. But the negative points of the game can’t be hidden this way: the amount of different areas is very limited (there are over 100 missions but just like 8 different areas, so you will re-visit some rooms and places quite a lot) and after a short amount of time the missions can get quite repetitive (there are only like six different goals). Moreoever some time limits in the missions seem to be set totally random, sometimes you finish with half an hour left and sometimes with barely 3 seconds. That’s also due to the fact that some bosses 'escape‘ randomly after a short fight and then you have to search them again (probably not the brigthest gaming mechanic). Besides your characters appearance lacks some good customization aspects, aside from 12 different color schemes (approximately 75% of them look awful…) for the two characters there’s nothing more. Some unlockable characters (e.g. the 3 other members of the KINGS) and areas after finishing the main game would have been a huge plus.
________________________________________________________________________________

Yes, the reviews and opinions for the game have been quite ambivalent. I think the problem is that many bakers and players expected a ‚pimped up‘-version of 'Metal Slug‘ with all its core points and elements. And with these expectations the game may disappoint easily. I bought it in hope to get a mixture of 'Mega Man‘ and 'Monster Hunter‘ – and I’ve never regret buying it because the game entertained me instantly.

All in all I guess the game would be a solid 7 out of 10 (or maybe a 6 if you dislike good old Mega or grinding) due to all the negative points (that are clearly there), but… I love the game. Sure I would have loved to enjoy even more areas and to customize my character to look different than my partners, but hey... -  I had a machine gun that fired some caustic missiles, which bounced of walls, splitted in little pellets and exploded on impact. That was one hell of a weapon. And I’ll never forget my shark-shaped-knife that shocked enemies on contact.

These two things alone have to improve the score by at least two points. Because of… reasons! And explosions. And think of the knifes! And the dogs in mecha-dog-suits. Yeah, never forget mecha suit Doge – ‚Metal Woof‘ ready for action!

reviewText: I had high hopes when I bought Merc Kings, I was expecting a Metal Slug/2D platformer. It is very far from that. The concept that drives most of this game is fetching objects/seek and destroy targets. While it doesn't sound bad, the problem is that it uses the same areas while examining every square inch for anything that might get overlooked. There are boss fights in the game, but after awhile they will give up and leave, which equals a failed mission. THAT DOESN'T MAKE ANY SENSE. You are already being timed on the stage, you have to find the boss, get fenced in and figure out the pattern, and they can ragequit. That is messed up.\n\nThe art style and music is great, but the idea of replaying the same areas over and over again for minor accomplishments got old very quick. I enjoy games where grinding is a requirement, but the incentive to continue with Merc Kings seems too far away with no variety in between.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings is a nice co-op action platformer which has a lot to offer as far as challenges and customization goes.

First off, there are 112 levels with more than 12 unique bosses which should keep you busy for a decent amount of time. Admittedly, the maps could use a little bit more variety. That's somewhat remedied by way most missions are structured. Each unique map is inherently large so each mission will cover only certain portions of the map (with the rest of it being totally optional).

The game also makes you consider resource management. While you don't need to do every single mission to 'beat' the game, you do however need to plan which resources to bring and decide when to best use them. For example, infiltration or capture missions will require you to make the best use of your C4 charges and shock bombs. Wasting one or more of each item can usually lead to failing the mission. This becomes even more important when speed runs come into play.

Another selling point of the game is the massive amount of gun parts and gun combinations available to you through progression. It opens up a lot of possibilities and it's amusing to see different combinations suggested on various videos and forum posts.

With all these things going for it, Mercenary Kings is not perfect. I'd reckon that the average Metal Slug player will be able to finish majority of the game without even fully scratching the surface as far as crafting goes. I feel that there's a lot of room for improvement when it comes to content. Personally, I feel that the game was too short seeing as I reached the final level long before I even got to halfway on all the crafting achievements.

My suggestion? Steam Workshop integration. This is another one of those games that will benefit a lot from workshop integration to add newly designed maps. BattleBlock Theater serves as a great example by giving the players access to the various blocks that make up the levels. A move like this will go a long way especially to reduce the boredom from having finished the game and moving onto crafting everything else.

My initial impression of this game would be at around 9/10. It was definitely fun but it needs something to fill the gap at the end of the game. For now I'd rate this game as a 7/10 since it is severely in need of user-generated content. Nevertheless, it's still an absolutely fun co-op experience. I do recommend getting the 4-pack.

reviewText:
No, Mercenary Kings is not like Metal Slug. If you want Metal Slug, go play Metal Slug.

Mercenary Kings is a 2D action-platformer with a variety of missions to undertake with generally non-linear level design. Yes, many of the missions share the same maps which I admit is a bit of a bummer, they could use some more variety since there is typically only 2-3 different maps per rank. Still, they're large and fun to explore and, with different types of missions including extermination (kill x amount of y), neutralize (kill boss), gathering (fetch items) and rescue (self-explanitory), among others, the different tasks do mix it up enough to keep it from getting completely stale.

What? Grinding? Yeah, there's grinding. You will need to grind materals to upgrade your gun's parts and upgrade your melee weapons. You will end up repeating missions over and over for mats. However, after the first run or two on a mission, you'll memorize the pattern of where everything is, making it much easier and faster to complete, so it's not as bad as it may sound.

The tunes are good, visuals are splended and charming, humor is amusing, characters are likable and the story works well for what it is.

Controls are responsive and both my old PS3 controller and my Logitech F310 work perfectly...do NOT attempt to play this with your keyboard or you're gonna have a bad time. I cannot stress that enough, do not use the keyboard, use a controller. Game client is stable; constant 60 FPS and no crashes to note.

The gun upgrade/mod system is fun and quirky, but could've been more refined and balanced, as the biggest changes to note are appearences, semi-auto/auto, clip size and reload time. While in theory this sounds nice since it boils down to preferences, many combanations lack fire-power so if you want major damage, you're limited to a few choice combanations. Considering this was one of the big selling points/features, it feels like it was unfinished and rushed.

I wish I could comment on the 4 player co-op, but I've never had an opportunity to try it.

Mercenary Kings isn't a game you can pick up and finish in an afternoon, it requires patience, time and investment. I recommend it, but it's not for everyone.

reviewText:
Considering Metal slug series being one of my all time favorites I really thought I'd love this gorgeous game. However the multitude of flaws just left me disapointed.

1) Missions are timed.
2) Enemies respawn when you reenter the map chunk/sector.
3) Enemies are bullet sponges.
4) Backtracking
5) If you want to kill (relatively) fast then your movement is hindered by the weight of hard hitting guns. HOWEVER, forget any skillfull evasion then, because in close quarters you will get hit no matter what. If you want to jump over attacking enemies, you are limited to peashooters which, guess what, take a long long time to kill all the enemies who are entrenched, shielded or immune to frontal attacks and are otherwise unavoidable like for example sniper or shield guy on a ledge where you need to get on. Prepare to jump over and over again in one spot until he's dead.
6) You can't shoot up while walking.
7) You can't change direction while attacking.
8) somewhat unresponsive movement

Combine 1 through 5 for constant and aggravating slog through enemies. Combine 5 through 8 for disapointing movement and gunplay.

reviewText:
I'm going to preface this review that this game is by no means perfect, and I have yet to totally finish all of the missions avaiable. That said...

This game is very *very* enjoyable. While the difficulty in later missions can be rather stress-inducing, the level of customizaton one can put into their guns allows you to feel like you're working to make your own private arsenal. Borderlands hands you the complete guns, and that's all well and good. Mercenary Kings gives you the pieces and lets you experiment. Do you put the pieces together to create a minigun that fires incendiary AP ammo? A shotgun that fires caustic buck? Or a 3 shot pistol that hits like a freight train with every bullet fired?

The choices are up to you. If customization, old school run-and-gun gameplay, and classic difficulty are up your alley, then Mercenary Kings is for you.

reviewText:
I really like this game for a lot of different reasons. Firstly is the music: the music is awesome i find myself listening to it all the time even well after i stopped playing this game. Secondly is the gameplay: its very satisfying and deliberate the controlls feel tight and the guns feel meaty with good sound effects and enemy death animation.

There is quite a lot of content however you do spend your time redoing things quite a lot in a sort of monster hunter fashion where you go to the same levels over and over to get materials however instead of just killing a boss there are different objectives for different missions like destroy something with explosives or save some hostages things like that. As for the bosses themselves they are pretty good they have attack patterns which can be quite difficult to master fighting against making them satisfying however unfortunately there isnt that many bosses in the game so you will find yourself fighting the same ones or varients on the same ones over and over.

This is a really solid game and can keep you going for a while if you enjoy it I spent a lot of time collecting different gun parts and trying different combinations however i eventually got bored of repeating the same areas over and over and moved on to other games. I would recommend getting it, and if you dont think it is your thing at least listen to the soundtrack because it is awesome!

reviewText:
Playing Mercenary Kings this past week, since its official release, is the most fun I've had with any game in years. That's not to say I don't enjoy the other games I play and adore, but this just tickles a fancy like none other. The rewards offered through progression, the challenges when the enemies ramp up, or when a new boss is introduced - they make playing endlessly entertaining. Now, much of the criticism the receives is due to a popular idea that the game is similar to Metal Slug. I've personally never played it, shame on me and such, but if you're looking for that experience, then you ought to play Metal Slug. This isn't like another game I've played, while it shares elements with many, it's an entity of its own. For many reasons this will remain one of my top picks for this year, if not longer, and there's no reason not to play it. Oh, get a controller.

April 10th revisions:

Oh... yeah... I'll have to recall some of those statements. The multiplayer is pretty much dying since launch, and the game isn't really that entertaining once you get your best gun. That being said, I got 60 hours of playtime out of it at its $15 launch price, so I'll definitely still recommend it. I just don't know how often I'll go back to it anymore. Whether I return to actively playing M.K. is really going to depend on how the Devs treat the game - as a product that could still use some improvements / additions, or as a finished game. Kinda feels melancholy leaving it behind for now...

reviewText:
After six hours, it just makes me want to play Metal Slug.

There are a lot of cool ideas here that I want to like a great deal. The art and music is beautiful, and  the mechanics that they draw from Borderlands, Monster Hunter, and Metal Slug are very cool in concept. But, therein lies the problem. There is tons of character and tons of concepts, and they just don't really gel together in a satisfying way. The beautiful art is done injustice by how stiff the animations are, and by how creepingly slow variations in environments and enemies are introduced. While the music is good, the sound effects are flat, and don't provide any real sense of punch to the action. The guns are incredibly flaccid and static, feeling more like gussied-up number hoses than firearms. Customizing the guns doesn't really feel meaningful or fun. As in Borderlands, all the variety in the world ends up just being wallpaper for a different set of slightly different numbers. This is compounded by the fact that new weapons cannot even be found in the wild, reducing the excitement of their procurement a great deal. Action is plodding with neither the fast pace of Metal Gear nor the precision of Mega Man, but a muddy, fuzzy middle-ground that isn't satisfying. After playing through the same map for the fourth time, the massive list of missions begins to look more like a list of chores than a set of badass missions.

When I set out to write this review I didn't mean for it to be this negative. After thinking about it, I've found myself terribly disappointed.

reviewText: This is a fun game with a surprisingly good plot. There's a lot of weapon variety, and is fun to play with a friend, but the netcode starts to fall apart with more than 1 friend. This game is what you would get if you crossed Metal Slug with Monster Hunter. You have a handful of prebuilt zones, with missions equivalent to Kill the Thing, Capture the Thing, Find the Stuff, Rescue the People, Destroy the Object, Go to the Spot, and so on. The Gameplay is reminiscient of Metal Slug or Contra, with a lot of weapon types and bullet types. There are numerous secrets on the maps that can help you advance your gear earlier (I hear people like sequence breaking) but it is all still a real challenge at the end of the game.

reviewText:
Looks great, doesn't play great.

Mercenary Kings has a wonderful visual style that seems clearly inspired by the wonderful Metal Slug series.

But the gameplay is more like Mega Man, except with less variety and more grinding. Respawning enemies, four-direction shooting, and a handful of large maps. The last five missions were on the same map, but Mercenary Kings is sending you back again to scour it for ten lumps of lead.

If you're expecting a fast-paced run-and-gun shooter, look somewhere else.
voteText: 15 of 21 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The art style, setting and characters capture the mid-90s shoot 'em up feel very well. Crafting your first machine gun after being stuck with the sub-par starter gun is hugely satisfying, as is completing a mission with all bonus objectives and enough resources gathered to buy several upgrades.

That said the gameplay turns out to be rather poor. On a regular basis players need to avoid enemy projectiles while firing at airborne enemies homing in on them and platforming, all at the same time. Sadly, the game lacks the silky smooth controls required to make this fun and instead just ends up being frustrating.
The actual gameplay takes the form of missions, each one with their own objective. Between them players can visit their homebase for upgrades and supplies. There are two major problems with this. First: missions take place in large locations which get recycled again, and again, and again. Secondly: no information is provided as to where in the freely traversable levels the current objective is located. As a result players are forced to scour the same places over and over again, often with endlessly looping background music, too. Combined with limited time for each mission things can become rather frustrating fast.

Other annoyances:
The camera is not overly intelligent.
Exponential grinding for better gear.
Jumping has a noticeable delay to it.
Jumping down larger heights leads to the character freezing for a moment upon landing.
Some enemies can fire diagonally, which players flatout can't.
Enemies may respawn the moment their spawn location is off screen.
Health items are few and far in between, making the gameplay rather unforgiving.
Health can be regenerated at field hospital, which act as save points. The health regen is slow enough to not be noticeable. The game doesn't bother mentioning that this health regen exists.
It's impossible to jump while crouching, making destructable platforms the player has to fire at while standing on them and exercise in patients.
Default grunt enemies on platforms above the players may randomly decide to drop down, giving no chance to walk away or kill them.
The first boss decided to leave once he was on low health. He came back eventually but not soon enough for there to be time to finish him off, leading to a failed mission. Who thought this was even a good idea?

reviewText:
The positive:
-Really nice pixel art.
-Can be fun (mostly at first).
-Good variety of enemies.
-The concept of secret objectives" is interesting
date:
even though it's developed poorly.

The neutral:
-The story. It's kind of bland but it can be skipped without an issue (just keep pressing "next" everytime the dialog windows show up after some key missions).

The negative:
-Gathering materials is a chore. Even upgrading your armor requires grinding (example: one armor requires 2 of a material that's only dropped by one boss; to make matters worse
recommended: it's not a guaranteed drop)\n-There are a lot of missions but they are really repetitive.\n-Maps are quite big
hoursPlayed:
which could be a good thing but you must check the map constantly to see if you are going to the right direction. Some missions actually don't tell you were the objectives are but luckily those are quite few.
-Crafting is kind of confusing but the worse thing is being constantly constrained by having to find materials.
-The food that can give you a boost on health (+ other temporary stats) must be grinded in the "hunting grounds" were you basically kill -mostly- harmless animals that provide no challenge. The whole thing looks like an unfinished featured that ended up being rushed.
-"Profencies" that you can get by crafting lots of stuff seem kind of nice but they are not worth the trouble of finding all the materials.
-The special "mods" that you can equip to your character are mostly kind of useless (although the one that assures that every enemy drops a material on death is extremely necessary to be able to craft weapons)
-Enemies have "strenghts" and "weaknesses" that you can learn about by talking to a guy in your camp and changing your bullets for each mission is so boring that you'll probably use the one with the higher attack number and disregard everything else.
-Weapons have a lot of different stats but they really don't change the playstyle.
-You can craft a lot of decorative stuff that serve no purpose except tempt you into wasting your materials. In my opinion it would have been better to see the base change as you completed missions.

Conclusion:
I can see a lot of potential in this game but it's full of really strange decisions that seem to be aimed at increasing the playtime of the game (but that's not the same as a game having a great replay-value).
in my opinion the game would have been a lot better without crafting and actually focusing in making combat and missions more varied."

reviewText:
Nice presentation, but the gameplay is lacking. The control is awkward, clumsy, and slow. The 'slow' part has been defended as being deliberate, but I found it grating. Regardless, you'll frequently find yourself slowly picking up an item when you needed to slowly duck, etc. The animation is great, but being unable to interrupt those animations when you want to do something else is painful.

The maps are sprawling and purposeless, and you'll be expected to play them over and over again to, for example, hunt down five snipers. With a fairly short time limit. They don't respawn, you have to find them, they're hiding. Is this fun?

If you're low on life, you can go to a med shack in the level somewhere! And wait inside for your health to sloooowly charge back up. Again, I ask you - is this fun? I understand that they've created a penalty (time) to offset the benefit you receive, but who wants to just stop and look at their character's idle animation for a whole ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minute while their life ticks up?

On paper everything seems good, but in practice ever part of this game is like a chore.

Análisis en Inglés y Español:
English:  It’s a decent game with badass pixel art and amusing plot yet I couldn’t bring myself to play for more than 4 hours, why is that you ask? the grind. In mercenary kings you’ll need to collect items to craft and customize weapons, rack up points to rank up and upgrade your base, it’s a fun concept but unfortunately you’ll just find yourself replaying the same map over and over again... so heads up fellas, game is fun but expect some tedious grinding.

Español:  Tenemos un juego bueno con pixel art muy trabajado y a pesar de ello no fui capaz de pasármelo, ¿Por qué? El grind. Gran parte del tiempo estarás buscando objetos para personalizar tus armas, o  recolectando suficientes puntos para avanzar de rango y mejorar tu base, si, suena genial en papel pero a la hora de la verdad significa que tendrás que jugar el mismo escenario una y otra vez.

Quedan avisados, el juego es decente pero deberás someterte a un grind puro y duro. Agregar además que el juego no es tan frenético como otros títulos en el género.

reviewText:
Every time I see Mercenary Kings brought up online, people get warned away from it for various reasons. Despite that, I'm here to say that it's gone down as one of my favorite games. Seriously, it's one of those where I'll play it for 2-3 hours and then have to force myself to play something else because I want to keep doing missions. It might not be for everyone, but let me share the good parts with all of you for a change.

So if you've somehow glossed over this one, Mercenary Kings is a side-scrolling shooter in the vein of Metal Slug. Unlike Metal Slug, however, you have a persistent character that you upgrade with new guns and mods and stuff over the course of a hundred or so missions. And those missions take place in huge, wide-open levels with lots of paths and secrets to find. Missions range from beating bosses to saving hostages to recovering intel to gathering materials. Materials are very important, of course, because they let you build new guns and mods and stuff.

See, there's something like 300 guns in the game, and you build each one piece by piece, using money from missions and materials from exploring and shooting dudes to unlock components. Those pieces can be mixed and matched to create monstrosities like a 32-round caustic shotgun. It's kinda like Borderlands if you could custom-build each gun. You can also build mods for yourself that give you major advantages, like speed boosts and regenerating health, or guaranteeing material drops and finding more money. There's also melee weapon crafting, cooking, and decorating your tent!

There's also a surprising amount of goofy-♥♥♥ story, too. About half the missions are bookended with short character scenes like this that move the plot along. You have to rescue people to expand your camp, and once in awhile something will happen to them, like I had to go save my gunsmith at the start of the rank 4 missions. The design for the characters is by the same guy who did the Scott Pilgrim beat-em-up that sadly never made it to PC, and everything is beautifully animated.

When the subject comes up, I've seen three big complaints about the game. The first is the bosses, and they're definitely one of the weak points. You have to actually find them in the level (unless you use the mod that shows their location on the map), usually in one of four locations, and they move around. Worse than that, they can run away while you're fighting them, meaning you have to follow them, though they're marked on your map after you find them once. They're not like Metal Slug bosses, either... they tend to be invincible until they reveal their weak point, so you have to learn their attacks and patterns. Once you do, though, they're not that hard. Capture missions ♥♥♥♥ing suck, though... you have to weaken the boss to a certain point and then hit them with a special grenade you can only carry like two of. I won't fault anyone who got stuck on a Capture mission and quit because of it.

The second complaint is that you have to grind for materials, and I really don't get that one at all. The first few mods that open up let you control material drops; one guarantees a drop from every enemy but lowers the chance of getting rarer ones, and another makes rare drops more likely but reduces the cash you get from missions. There are no real rare drops, either. Each enemy has up to three items they drop, but they tend to be spread around so that almost every material is a common drop from something. The only hard to get ones are boss drops, but you can find those hidden on most levels in secret rooms, and they're always in the same boxes so you can get as many as you want during missions there.

The last is that it's repetitive, and really that's going to be entirely up to the player. There are ten ranks of missions, with 10-12 missions per rank. Missions tend to take place on the same 2-4 maps per rank, so if you get tired of doing different things on the same levels, then yes, it's going to be repetitive. After almost 30 hours I haven't really tired of any of the missions and still go back and replay old ones to get extra materials and try to beat the par times. It's not perfect, but I got absolutely addicted to it and I didn't even play it co-op. Honestly, it's not a Metroidvania game but it's scratching the same itch for me that the old GBA Castlevania games did. If you like item hunting and gear customization in your platform games, I think it's a blast.

reviewText: Clearly inspired by the Metal Slug and Metal Gear series of games, Mercenary Kings combines some elements of the two to create a rather mediocre action platformer. You collect tons of materials to create dozens of guns that feel more or less the same, spend a lot of time repeating same levels again and again, and read pointless flavor-text dialogue that tries to pretend there's some interesting story going on behind the scene.\nThe pacing of the game is hurt severely by a slow progression, grind for materials and lack of variety in combat - sure, there's some items you can use but they take up a slot in the inventory and its awkward to find a right moment to use them. It honestly feels like a chore - in Metal Slug games you had a few neat tools to fight the enemies (guns, grenades, tanks), big interesting levels with tons of unique hazards, plus the pacing of progression was fast and exciting.\nMK managed to copy the face of Metal Slug to some degree, but not the core formula that made that series fun to play.

reviewText:
It is amazingly fun to craft realistic gun parts, screw them together as you think, and see if the product is any good on missions. The Missions are cool too, you get various elimination, some gathering, some hostage freeing, and of course boss missions - including related sub-missions and secret goals.

Regarding the moral side, it seems brutal to murder so many people, instead of robots or something. But then again, the description of some enemies clearly says that they don't just look the same, but they're cloned and bionicly modified abominations. (That's possible due to the mandrake formula, the plot key)

Oh, and this games multiplayer works really nicely on local and LAN. I've hardly experienced noteworthy lag, and even if you encounter asyncronous enemies, it doesn't seem to matter - the instance you see is the instance that can take and deal damage, and syncronisation appears to give up eventually, which means no rubberbanding.

All in all, awesome Arcade Fun for alone or with friends!

reviewText:
While Mercenary Kings may look like a Metal Slug clone, it's more like a combination of Mega Man and Monster Hunter. However, MK doesn't work nearly as well as the games it's inspired by. The shooting mechanics have some annoyances (you can't shoot upwards while moving) and while there's customization, the weapons still end up feeling somewhat same-y. There are many different enemy types with their own patterns.

While the shooting mechanics are alright overall, there are multiple huge negative points. First of all: The enemies respawn once you leave the part of the screen where they spawn. This is INSANELY annoying. What makes it worse is that after you die, you respawn at the start of the level/at a checkpoint. That means that you have to redo a big chunk of the level once you die. To add to the monotony, you'll have to do the same levels over and over again due to the mission system. And the shooting action is not nearly good enough to justify that kind of grinding.

Just play Metal Slug instead. Or Monster Hunter.

reviewText: If you've ever enjoyed a single sidescrolling run and gun game in your life, get this without hesitation. This is probably better than most of them anyway. It scrolls sideways (and up an down too!) and you both run and gun in a very pleasant manner. Hopefully this being the game's only fault in my mind will tell you something.

reviewText: Forget about Metal Slug because Mercenary Kings is here. Don't come into this game expecting a Metal Slug rehash. It's got guns and cute characters, but that's as far as the similarities go. It's retro done well, if Retro City Rampage is retro done wrong. (But that's another story, because I'm not reviewing that game.) Please play Mercenary Kings with one or more friends because it is a game best enjoyed through co-op. I guess it's a valid criticism that the missions are repetitive, but Mercenary Kings isn't really about the missions. This is game about the journey (but it's not Journey). It's fun to customize your guns and to slowly get better and better at killing enemies. This game is challenging but it's never really unfair. The reload mechanic is a deliberate design choice so you can't just hold shoot and win." And even if you just ignore all that
date: you still have a game that looks and sounds great. The aesthetic is charming and the characters are kinda one-dimensional I guess (or are they two-dimensional?)
recommended: but they're still pretty likable. Even the dialog is well-done. Bravo Zulu
hoursPlayed: Tribute. And Tanko Yankee. And please make a sequel."

reviewText: Have you ever wanted to build a gun out of a toilet, a skull, a cat, AND a rifle scope? Well, look no further! In Mercenary kings, you and some buddies can play this side-scroller cooperatively, collecting resources, completing objectives, upgrading your characters... and building guns! Lots and lots of guns. There is some re-use of environments, and some of the enemies can be a little cheap, but the humor, pixel art, and objectives will keep you hooked!

i liked this game lot, it's a good game to play with friends.

reviewText:
Definitely a masterpiece of the independent game developmentMercernary kings is good, real good, and that on every level it extends to, with no exceptions as far as I know.
Time to complete 10 to 35hrs, depending on how much you want to do
Time to 100% 60+hrs
Difficulty: [■■■□□] - Mildly Challenging
Genre: Shoot them Up
Here, have some bullet points. I insist:
Pretty big lifetime (Took me about 35 hours to clear every mission)
High Skillcap
Decently balanced, it never gets annoying
Awesome Mob design (wide range of ennemies)
Very well achieved Boss Fights, which depend almost only on skill (more on that later)
Pleasant level design
Amazing Soundtrack
Super cool graphics and animations
The game handles very well, and unless you go for 100% completion rate, it is never annoying in the slightest.
-With a game pad, it's very fluid and responds pretty well to what you try to do
-The wide variety of ennemies forces you to improve your gampelay and strategies

The maps are very various, and they each have their own little ambiance, mobs, loot, and associated weapon crafts.
-They are also quite wide, each having their own secrects and utilities to missions, and even farming

You have a very important freedom of playstyle, due to the large amount of upgrades/guns.
-Proficiencies and Bionic Mods allow you to adapt to the situation/mission, and develop your own playstyle

The story (albeit quite simple) is entertaining, and the character development really goes to contribute to the friendly and funny aspect of the game.

The Bosses are a game of their own, because of how well done they are :that is that each fight contains its own strategies, usually very different from the others. On top of that, there is a pretty big variety of them for a game of this size !

reviewText:
When I first saw Mercenary Kings, I became very interested in the game and it looked very exciting to me. The graphics and the gameplay strongly resemble those of the Metal Slug series. There’s the side-scrolling and 2D platforming that old school gamers have appreciated.

The plot of Mercenary Kings is about a mercenary who is part of a resistance group that is doing battle with a villainous organization known as The Claw. The narrative quickly becomes irrelevant as you start off in camp and learn to customize your mercenary character. There is no voice acting, so you have to read the dialog text to understand what is really going on. The lack of relevance the narrative has does not bring the game down since gameplay tries to be the strength of the game.
Upon playing this game I first realized how awkward the keyboard controls are. There is no mouse to be used in the game, but the keyboard makes the gameplay feel like a drag. I firmly believe that fans of the Metal Slug series would be best advised to use a controller or gamepad to have any fun with this game. Another aspect of the gameplay that feels like a drag is the repetitive nature of the battles with The Claw. You have a limited number of lives and after each death you will have to face the same enemies and this feels quite tedious. Using keyboard controls is difficult when trying to press buttons to shoot, jump, and roll.

The graphics are pixelated, but that’s not too bad for a game that’s trying to be an old school, 2D side scroller. If the game had more variety in its levels, the replay value would be exponentially higher. I really wanted to like Mercenary Kings because of its concept of being of resistance fighter battling an organization of villains and the various characters to choose from and customize. Weapons can also be customized so that your mercenary can leave camp for battle with better gear.  I can only recommend this game to those with a game controller or gamepad and do not care much about the quality of the narrative. If you’re a gamer who is accustomed to using the keyboard/mouse combination, I would not recommend Mercenary Kings unless you are willing to commit yourself to playing with a game controller or gamepad.  I give this game a score of 6/10.

reviewText: If you had of asked me if I would recomend this game a week ago, I would have. However since then I have gotten to the later stages and now I see this game is everything I used to hate about old school games. In the later levels the Devs decided to make it more challenging by adding jump mazes that require a high end controller to do. If you are trying with a cheap controller or a Keyboard.. good luck...  And the time limits imposed on those missions make it so you are trying to rush though which of course increases the chance you will fail due to missing a jump.  And mix that all with the fact that there is usually more then one way to go on the map to your objective however some ways are blocked by doors that require C4 and since you can only carry 1 C4 that means if you choose a direction incorrectly once then the short time expires and you lose because of that.\nits really to bad. The game is a ton of fun all the way up to captain with a few annoyances here and there and then you just hit this wall of missions that suck all the fun from the game and induce extreme frustration.

reviewText:
As a big fan of Metal Slug-style 2D shooters, I was really looking forward to playing this. The pixel-art is fantastic, the gunplay is great and modding your weapons can yield some interesting results.

But sadly, the game just starts to feel very dull and repetive after a while.
I can't quite put my finger on it, but after a while it just didn't pull me in anymore. It feels like it lacks flair or intensity. Coming back to something like Metal Slug, the action feels very kinetic and constant. Mercenary Kings tends to feel very slow and meandering.

It can still be fun and maybe I'll give it more a chance someday, but at this time? I don't think it's worthwhile.
And if you're going to try it, get it on sale because it sure as hell is NOT worth 20 dollars.

reviewText:
You'll probably hear this compared to Metal Slug a bunch, but the only similarities are it's a side-scrolling shooter. Maybe the comparisons come from how good the game looks, sounds and plays. It's a lot of fun. There's a really cool gun customisation system where you pick and choose parts from a heap of different weapons, all with their pros and cons, leaving you with so many options for how you want to kill things. As I mentioned before, the game looks awesome, the sprites and animations are great, The music is so damned catchy, and the controls are solid, controlling your character just feels good.
It's in early access at the moment, so it's still missing about 40 out of the 100 missions it's supposed to have, so keep an eye out for when it's released.

Oh yeah, it's 4 player co-op, 4 player online AND splitscreen, and both work really well, and it's definitely a lot more fun with more people.

reviewText: I haven't delved too much into this game but from what I've played I really like the old school side scrolling 2d aspect to this game. I think the most common description of this game would be something along the lines of Metal Slug x Borderlands. Where the gameplay is obviously like Metal Slug but the be all end all is to upgrade your weapons, armor and mods through pickups. I think at most that's where this game kinda diverts from the two games mentioned and probably falls closer to the gathering games found in MInecraft or Terraria. There is no leveling method from what I've seen and the only way to increase your health and weaponry is by increasing your money by doing missions and picking up material drops found during those missions. At first, the game may seem difficult like most shooters will but once you get a decent upgrade going the game will start feeling like classic shooters from days past. I think what sold me on this game was when I was rolling with another player online (4 player co-op) and she was carrying around the spread gun. That's right a spread gun from Contra!

reviewText:
If you're looking for a good ol' fashioned SHOOT 'EM UP game, this is the one you're looking for. A mixture between an already perfectioned platform shooter Metal Slug, and the RPG element of Borderland as the cream on the cake makes this game the utmost best platform-shooter I've played in a long time.

There are some cons about this game I'd like to add, so here's a list I put together after playing this game for 5 hours straight.

PROS:

+ Fun gameplay with a lot to do and master.
+ Awesome pixel-graphics with great details for violent man-slaughter.
+ The replay value is there, and with multiplayer you can bring your mates to join up the massacre.
+ Huge maps to explore and conquer.
+ Fun characters with a lot of personalities and hilarious slap-stick humour.
+ The price for the game fits for what you get.
+ IT'S A MODERN & UPGRADED VERSION OF METAL SLUG.

CONS:

- The missions are quite repetitive.
- Also, ALL missions have a time limit, and with random missions on random maps, it can easily be overwhelming about what
to do and how to do them, not to mention WHERE you are supposed to be (a minimap would be helpful).
- It takes some time to get used to the game mechanics and the weapon-builder system.
- If you don't bring the right weapons to the right missions, it's easy to botch yourself.
- Tends to turn a bit tedious if you play the game alone.

All in all, this is a motherhumping awesome game, and I'd rate it 6/6 within a heartbeat. But this is a game that is enjoyed best with some company, so make sure you got some pals that'll join you on the task to save the world!

reviewText:
Not a bad game, but sometimes feels like the whole is much less than the sum of it parts. Mercenary Kings came dangerously close to being great but stumbled near the finish line and crashed hard. Maybe it's me. I'm going to recommend, because it's not a bad game in any way and it features a pretty cool concept. Ultimately it's fun and i've been playing it longer than i initially thought i would. And i still want more. If you're into pixel art, retro styled action platformers, this is a very solid, if very uninspired game.

Mercenary Kings has some good ingridients, but doesn't seem to click too well. It takes some pretty bland cliches of 80/90 over the top cartoons, villains and macho bs heroes but doesn't use them to create anything compelling. It rehashes cliches for the sake of rehashing cliches which is a shame because the game has some pretty good elements.

Ordinarily, i'd expect a game to come up with a cool concept then ruin it by being lazily half-arsed or rushed, but Mercenary Kings actually has good art and sound. I can't blame the developers for lacking effort because it's certainly there. The characters are drawn and animated with style and their dialogue fits the brash and cliched design. But they're unlikable and almost ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I don't expect great depth but they're very cookie cutter" and not very memorable

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WR-HgfkLX0o

Above is my video impression of the game.

Mercenary Kings is an great looking side scrolling shoot'm up.,Inspired by the likes of Metal Slugs, Megaman, or Contra. The game is pretty damn fun and addictive. It has an interesting custom / upgrade system for your gear, where you have to farm for materials and cash to create new gadgets.

Though the game play is fun and challenging, it can be a little repetitive at times.

Pros:
- Great audio and visuals
- Interesting and unique style
- Great upgrade system
- Lots of replay
- Controls are deliberate and responsive

Cons:
- Can be repetitive
- Map could be more streamlined
- Some times can be hard to find a random online game/player

reviewText:
Modernized Metal Slug with style.

There are a lot of throwback games nowadays, but this one just brings so much to the table that it’s worth checking out. Not many games have made use of the delicate pixel art that Metal Slug introduced us to. Why you might say? I think it’s because it requires a lot of work and the style has a lot of detail and could be daunting for the developers. However this game is just beautiful pixel art throughout the whole game, never getting repetitive or unfulfilling.

The game takes the shoot-em-up game, arcade style gameplay and mixes it with metoridvania free-roaming and item-gathering concepts to pimp up the Metal Slug-like gameplay to a more modernized version.

With hundreds of mission, carried out on several map levels, with endless of materials, gadgets, tech, armor and weapons to build and customize this game has shown us what the shoot-em-up genre will look like in the future.  With all its content and lots of hard to catch achievements, this game will keep you coming back for more, for a very long time.
I could not recommend this enough.

One note: Gamepad over Keyboard, any day.

reviewText:
I have really mixed feelings on this game but at the end I would give it a 4/10 (10 is the best).
Pros:
Graphics
Weapons-you-can-personnalize: I like to find powerfull combination adapted to new enemies
Reloading: brings a bit of strategy in fights
Enemies: many different enemies and bosses, each with their own weakness to aim.
Cons:
Repetitivity: you have a lot of missions in the same environment then you change of map, but it's the same kind of missions with a higher difficulty.
Difficulty: rises slowly then there's a gap I haven't managed to crossed. I couldn't finish the game.
Enemies: seriously, what's this idea of enemies coming back when you just left the part of screen where you've killed them? There should be a timer before they come back because it's really painful.
Dialogues; the story is not bad but dialogues are bad. Humor may vary between people, but I think the one in dialogues is bad.
Characters: for a game you can play up to 4 players, why is there only 2 caracters you can play? Is it laziness or lack of time/money? When I saw the introduction video, I thought the 4 guys in it would be available.

In the end, it's not a bad game, I had fun with but it leaves me a bitter taste. In terms of gameplay, I really prefer Broforce (you have to give it a try with friends) which offers more variety, fun and modern mechanics.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings = Metal Slug + Monster Hunter (with just a dash of metroidvania). Unfortunately as good as this combination sounds, Mercenary Kings doesn't live upto any of those games, instead it seems to awkwardly straddle the divide between them.

If your expecting a fast paced sidescrolling run and gun game like Metal Slug or Megaman X, you will be disappointed. Movement is in no way terrible, but in comparison to games that excel in the genre the characters will seem sluggish (I know that running speed is affected by equipment weight) and the controls will feel loose and a bit unresponsive (especially jumping). Also being unable to shoot diagonally seems like a big oversight for a game like this. Don't be expected to be oneshotted by enemies but at the same time be prepared to spend more taking enemy grunts down. Once again though this doesn't make Mercenary Kings a bad experience, you just need to manage your expectations.

Anyone familar with Monster Hunter will be right at home with the way that Mercenary Kings handles missions and crafting. Missions are selected from an npc in the hub basecamp, mostly fetch/kill quests which take place over a handful of levels (encouraging you to explore new areas of each map) with a few boss battles sprinkled through each tier. A new tier becomes available after completing specific missions which usually involve the introduction of a new boss, which can be captured or killed depending on the mission and/or your preference. Enemies(and Bosses) will drop items needed to craft new gun parts and knives. Just like Monster Hunter to get your favourite equipment you will find yourself grinding. All though this formula worked great with Monster Hunter, unfortunately Mercenary Kings doesn't pull it off half as well. Although maps in Monster Hunter were reused in every mission, you didn't have to wade through 15 min of the same pattern of enemies to get to your objective, you could generally just run there. Weapons in Monster Hunter varied greatly, feeling very different to use and with very different stats, in Mercenary Kings it really just boils down to dps. I also feel like there are some real balancing issues with the different gun types. Who wants to grind for gun parts when the guns just feel like reskins of your current weapon. For grinding to be viable gameplay in a game like this bosses really have to be something special, with random attack patterns and unpredictable AI, every fight needs to feel different. This is also something that Monster Hunter gets away with but Mercenary Kings seems to struggle with.

I don't know if this review will help anyone and I really have just scratched the surface on what to expect but overall although there a lot of questionable design choices in Mercenary Kings, I HAVE enjoyed my time playing it, especially with my friends. It may not compete with other games from similar genres, but what it does do is provide a enjoyable unique hybrid experience, and for that it was worth my money.

reviewText:
This is one of the few games I put aside to never play again ever.
Before two hours of playing cut in a few sessions, the gameplay quickly became tedious due to going back and forth in the same levels again and again, killing respawing ennemies and waiting for drops (come on, it this a MMORPG of some kind ? In any case, please, this is certainly no Metal Slug, stop comparing it to that game).
The customization mechanics do seem to add depth but that won't make up for the entire gameplay, sorry.

Very disappointing considering the nice art, solid animation by Paul Robertson and his friends.

Online co-op is based on an unconvenient matchmaking system which I couldn't make good use of but it may work better for you.

Please note that the game probably plays much better if you are playing local co-op, because exploration becomes more efficient and fun through communication and exchanges.

reviewText:
This game is...actually pretty boring.

I loved the visual style of the game and thought it would play close to a Metal Slug or Contra like game with customizable weapons. Though from what I've experienced it seemed more like a watered down Mega Man game with some mild RPG mechanics.

It's not a badly made game in any sense, but it feels a bit too sluggish for an action junkie to enjoy.  The fact that it's mission based and most of the time you'll be farming materials to make new guns parts and what-not adds to that.

Pros:
-It has very appealing aesthethics and animation
-There's a lot of customization options for your gun (though not right out of the box).
-It has online multiplayer (up to 4 people)

Cons:
-You gotta farm a lot to be able to get better gun parts (which is bad for those who just want to get into the action).
-The Action itself is pretty slow paced (it also doesn't seem at all challenging)
-Playing with friends doesn't make it any more hectic and actually slows it down even more since you have to wait
for each player to catch up to go to the next area of the mission.

In Short:
If you like a action based games that play similar to classics like Metal Slug, Contra, or Mega Man. This is probably not the game for you.

If you happen to like farming and don't mind slow pased action and find quirky and bouncy artstyles a good enough reason to buy a game. Then go ahead and get this title.

Either way I recommend you wait to get it on sale before grabbing a copy for yourself or a friend. I honestly did not like the game enough to recommend a full price purchase.

reviewText:
A real tragedy.

Floaty, mushy, bizarrely timed controls and a repetitive to the point of absurdity mission structure completely decapitate a very very good looking game. The enemies are bullet sponges and the levels are clumsily constructed and monotonous -- which actual hinders your ability to complete the 'hunt the thing' or 'hide and seek' mission objectives.

It's a shame the probably >90% of everyone that plays Mercenary Kings will never actually see the vast majority of the goregeous assets.

reviewText:
I normally don't write reviews but mercenary kings is an exception for me
.
.
.
So, I've had this game since it's first early access release, but only started playing it now, I went through a couple ranks, and so far I have a positive opinion, let me describe you the gameplay

MECHANICS: ISN'T FULLY DISCOVERED FOR ME YET
So the core part of the mechanics, is that you have 1 map per 1 rank, the maps are big, in different missions you must roam the map to complete the objectives. That's the missions part, now let's get to the camp part. The camp is a place you roam between the missions, it's split into two parts:
1) The main camp
2) Hunting grounds (You can go here to get animals' food, and harvest fruits)
The whole point of the camp is that it consists of different members, that do different functions, you can go here to customize your weapons, cook yourself a meal, forge yourself a knife, choose a mission, search for games, customize your tent (Your bragging place, that you can show to different players that join you, here you can have a banner, and ornament, and three of your favourite weapons sets created by youself shown), upgrade armor. Although I didn't play through the game fully yet, this is probably all of the functions that will be available. At first not all of these functions will be available, you must get them through specific missions

GUNS N' KNIVES. THEIR STATS
This part feels very entertaining, you can create a bunch of variations of EVERYTHING, quick advice though, negative stats can make your gun better, depending on what you're trying to do. About knives, you can't customize them, but there's so much of them, that you wouldn't want to.

PLATFORMING
Very good, uhh, I think that's all I can say, there's a weight system though, it's determined by your knifes and guns.

reviewText:
This game isn't awful. It's just a weak Metal Slug ripoff. The missions all take place in the same locales, and the objectives are always kill x of this enemy or collect x of this item. Some times you have to capture a boss, but there is no explanation beforehand as to how you do this. I'd battled through the stage only to mistakenly kill the boss because I'd ran out of the item needed to capture him. Both yours and the enemies projectiles are painfully slow. There are only two directions you can shoot in whilst not jumping. Up and left / right. This makes fighting certain flying enemies a major pain in the balls. Especially when they knock you off of a ladder or a zipline when you're just trying to get from A to B. The boss fights are rubbish too. You do so much damage to the boss and then he walks through into the background and appears at a random location on your map. And unless you pay for one of your people to spot the boss, you're left running through the stage blind. Battling the respawning enemies. The worst are easily the slow moving flying drones. Slowly followed by these little jumping turnip headed ♥♥♥♥ers. They are very difficult to hit unless you have a shotgun, due to them springing about all over and your projectiles being telegraphed.
I haven't enjoyed my time on this game at all. And would only recommend it to somebody who is bored of staring down and punching themselves in the ♥♥♥♥.

4/10
