reviewText:
There is a really great game with powerful crafting abilities hiding underneath an extremely unfriendly introduction.

Here's some of the problems with the game's first rank:
1) Your starting weapon is weak, short ranged, and has a small clip to boot.
2) They chose one of the worst maps ever for the starting missions. Confusing layout, lots of little unconnected rooms, and tons of elevation changes; apparently just to screw with you.
3) Very poor mission choices to start with, including a gathering mission and a rescue 8 hostages mission which, combined with the annoying map layout and the fact that the stuff you're looking for isn't marked on the map (most missions are kind enough to give you an 'x' to head towards,) seemed to have been chosen specifically to weed out new players.
4) Your extremely limited choices to upgrade, once you finally manage to pick up some crafting supplies, really don't give you the tools to significantly modify your weapon.

All told, it'll take you somewhere around an hour and a half to get out of that horrible slog.

So why am I recommending this game?

Because as soon as you start to move up the ranks, all kinds of new stuff is unlocked which greatly improves the experience. You start getting all kinds of real choices for your weapon: bullet hose machine gun or single-shot sniper rifle? Shotgun or pistol? Submachine gun or magnum? Your choice! Mix and match pieces from each to completely customize your experience and unlock the ability to use special ammo types with a variety of effects.

You'll also start seeing some interesting choices for hand-to-hand weapons: Do you take the tiny knife that won't weigh you down, or a massive sword or spear that can inflict massive damage at range (and never runs out of ammo!)

The ability to choose two perks that can really help customize your character. Need to throw more bullets at things? Double your magazine size or pick up faster shooting. Looking for crafting materials? Make it so that enemies always drop items and/or make them drop rare items more often.

Better maps!  Now, not going to say it's all roses (I really didn't like the temple, which is another extremely vertical level), but it's all a step up from the starting jungle map.

Mission choices! Past the first rank, you generally don't need to complete every mission to get to the next rank. Have a mission that's kicking your ♥♥♥? Skip it, then come back in a rank or two with a bigger, better gun.

Pros/Cons:
+ Great pixel graphics.
+ Great music.
+ Great customization.
+ Epic boss fights.
- Horrible starting levels.
- Control scheme that sometimes feels like it's fighting you.
- Why can't I shoot diagonally? (Most of) the enemies can!

Overall:
+Worth the starting slog.

reviewText:
Do you like Metal Slug? Do you like Monster Hunter? Do you like Paul Robertson?

Yes, yes, and yes, get this game. Finally finished after being worked on and tempered for quite a while, this game is the best we can hope for a 2d mash-up of shoot 'em ups and grind 'em ups.

==THE GOOD==
Amazing spritework from Paul Robertson, or at least designs. Whether or not he did the full animating, it's still a very impressive job. The intro is stellar for setting up an actiony arcade game.

Quick fun and good multiplayer capability. Grab some friends and rampage around! Loot is shared, where one person needs to pick it up and the rest of your group gets the rewards, so having someone branch off to look for supplies isn't a bad thing. Plus, with reviving teammates if they get in over their head, and no friendly fire, having a partner helps.

Gun customization. Slap together your weapon with multiple options. There are sets, yes, and some parts don't work so well with others, but for the most part you're free to craft your gun with whatever you grab.

==THE BAD==
The grind. It's not as terrible as some games can be, Monster Hunter or certain other games considered. But to make some weapons, mods, or ornaments, be prepared to run a mission well into the double digit numbers. Completionists would do well to have patience for this game.

Enemy repetition. Not until about the halfway point in the game do enemies become very varied. Not a huge problem though.


Ultimately, great purchase and fun game.

reviewText:
Imagine what would happen if you took Monster Hunter, and then put it into a semi-retro 2D military setting.

That's Mercenary Kings. Mercenary Kings is not Metal Slug and should not be treated as such. It's 2D military Monster Hunter down to the core.

What does that mean? Well, for starters, there's a certain set of areas that you'll be redeployed to again and again and again, and larguely these areas will have the same enemies every time, but your goal will be different depending on the mission you take. You might have to gather certain items, destroy a certain object, rescue hostages, clear an area of enemies, kill a boss, and so on. All of these missions also have a time limit, so you can't just take your sweet time looking around, but you'll pretty quickly learn the levels and enemies as you run missions in the areas. All of these are elements pulled right out of Monster Hunter really.

What's somewhat different is the crafting. Yes, you go out, gather materials, and them come back to base and cough up some resources and cash to get new equipment. That's the same as Monster Hunter. Where it differs is the depth of customization in your weapon. You get to mix and match parts of your gun to produce different stats and behavior, so you can take a magnum and stick machine gun parts on it if you wish to do so. That said, in reality, what you've really got is a pistol, a machine gun, a burst rifle, a shotgun, and a homing missile launcher, and beyond that you'll just be tweaking stats to manage reload times, reload ease (the game uses an active reload system that can give you a 10% damage boost if you do it perfectly), accuracy, damage, ammo capacity (before reloading, you have infinite ammo otherwise), fire rate, weight, and bullet propeties (homing, elemental, bursting into smaller projectiles, scatter shot, large size, and rebounding). It's actually pretty simple, but there's certainly some joy in tweaking your weapon to suit the situation or match your play style.

Now let's talk about enemies. The enemies in the game all follow very simple behavior patterns, including the bosses, and there's not generally many of them on screen at once. The game certainly has some difficulty when you first encounter enemies and don't know what to expect, but once you learn them it does become somewhat repetative. After all, you're going to be fighting the same enemies on the same levels quite a bit. Nonetheless, I certainly find some joy in being able to rush through levels that I once had difficulty with. That said, as said, the bosses are pretty simple too, so while this game share a whole lot in common with Monster Hunter, don't expect to get the same feeling of accomplishment from downing a tough big bad, because there's nothing quite that scale here.


In any case, the game is pretty fun, but just keep in mind that it's really a Monster Hunter styled game, and that means you're going to spend a whole lot of time looking at the same scenery and fighting the same enemies. If you want an arcade action game with a bunch of hectic levels, this isn't it.

reviewText:
If you took the art of Scott Pilgrim: The Game, mixed it with the reloading of Gears of War, the weapon drops of Borderlands, and the gameplay of Metal Slug..it wouldn't sound very original, now would it?

But despite that, this game is awesome. The multiplayer makes it highly entertaining, plus the large maps and weapon building mechanic keep things from getting boring.

Best of all? Couch co-op! This game's seriously worth getting, and continues to get better.

reviewText: I played this game for the first time with a friend, skipping the single player and going straight for multiplayer when playing a game for the first time (something I do often) is usually a hassle, but with this game it wasn't. simply speaking to the robot in the hub area will allow you to invite friends to play with you. We were using skype, so the in game voice chat was not needed, as decent as it was, and turning it off (a task which is usually a minor hassle) was as easy as a couple button presses. Controls are easy, you move with WASD, do the various actions with IJKL, and reload with the spacebar. The pixels are incredibly easy on the eyes and gameplay is simple and to the point.

reviewText:
I want to like this game.

I like Metal Slug, and this gives at least tribute to it.
But after a hour of it, I'm already done. It does nothing of what made Metal Slug a good game.
Damage on contact from enemies instead of knifes+bullets only.
Back-tracking with no clear information.
Bosses you have no idea where to fight.
Respawning enemies as soon as you go out of the screen.
5 seconds load when you finished or start a mission before it goes to the brief/debrief screen (you can literally die in this period).

I've been looking for 10 minutes for a boss in a level. It came once, but I can't find it anymore. I've tried--the boss came in some sort of arena. Finding another arena, I wondered when no boss appeared. And again, and again.
The game is slow, tedious, the constant reloading is meh at best, the tutorial is not interesting and hard to follow (make it a straight line, not such a mess!)..
Mercenary Kings is a game I'd like to like, but I can't.

reviewText:
This game is almost good, but even after only a couple missions, I can see where the bad reviews are coming from. The shooting mechanics are decent, but not perfect. For instance, you can't shoot upwards while moving, which feels unintuitive and confining. There are also some irritating things about the way the menus work that should clearly be changed, but this stuff is minor compared to the main flaws...

As much as I am growing sick of games about collecting and crafting, I think I would actually enjoy collecting materials in this game, if it weren't for the fact that enemies respawn in EXACTLY the same spot. And I don't mean the same spot every time you play the mission, or even every 30 seconds, I mean as soon as their spawn is off screen. This does two terrible things: it forces you to manage the screen's position or risk being mobbed by the same enemies repeatedly, and it makes material collection extremely trivial. For example, the first mission I played was in the hunting grounds, to acquire two pelts. This doesn't mean exploring the map like it should. What it means is knowing where one fox spawns, then repeatedly trying to kill it before it RUNS FIVE FEET AND DISAPPEARS FOR NO REASON. Then I move to one side and run back and do the same thing again until the mission ends.

If I can bring myself to continue the game, I can't imagine changing my opinion later on. As others have said, this is a game that's ultimately about grinding for materials and crafting, but that one single design choice completely undermines that. Enemies need to spawn in random locations, and they probably need to NOT RESPAWN AT ALL during a single mission. Even if the overall amount of content in the game is limited, I believe those two changes would make the game infinitely more playable than it is. As things stand, I wouldn't really recommend this to anyone.

If the game could be heavily redesigned from what it is, I could see it improving in one of two ways. The first would be to have more authored content, distinct levels that were meant to be played in a linear way from start to finish, but could be repeated to collect more ingredients, money, etc. In Metal Slug, I played those levels over and over for no reason except that they were fun. By comparison, I get bored of a Mercenary Kings level before I even finish it once, because it's so stagnant.

The second option would've been to move towards heavier randomization, perhaps procedural areas that would mean not repeating content at all, but could perhaps result in less interesting levels. But even in its current state, the only thing that needs to change to vastly improve this game is the enemy spawns, which seems like a totally doable change to me, though it'd be a fair amount of work to rebalance objectives and alter the enemy spawns to suit it. But IMO, it needs to be done or the game is not worth playing. Which is a shame, because there is a lot of stuff to like about it.

reviewText:
I want to really like this game. The animations and visual style is really great, but some parts of the gameplay destroy my attempts at enjoyable experience.

A few key problems that pull this game from greatness:

- no diagonal aiming
- enemy respawns and time limit discourage the player from exploring
- the looting feels like a chore
- inventory/carrying system is not very good (C4 doors I can already see being an awful experience)

To the developers who did the work on the animated sprites and defining the visual style, as well as whomever crafted the awesome music for this game: I applaud ye.

To the developers who half-♥♥♥♥♥ some aspects of the gameplay and level design: I do not.

reviewText:
First of all, let me say the game is really pretty. It has a great retro aesthetic that moves and feels like an SNK classic. The most obvious comparison being Metal Slug of course. The music is good as well and captures that same era perfectly and is generally catchy and unobtrusive.

Missions are boring and styled after MMO/RPG cliches of kill so many of this, gather so many of that, etc. and the big kicker is you can't double up on missions. Each one must be completed separately which wouldn't be unbearable if the game didn't re-use the -exact- same map for 10 or so missions. Meaning that you see the same map, with the same infinity re spawning enemies, far too much. Especially since there isn't much in the way of enemy variety nor are enemies challenging or satifying to eliminate. Even bosses are a bit of a bore considering the slower paced nature of the combat and the GoW style active reload system. Which in a better developed or more fully realized combat system would be extremely satisfying.

The game also makes a big deal out of the different gun parts and plethora of combinations possible but the sad truth is most are pretty worthless and to be frankly honest a base nearly unmodified pistol will do just as well as a custom designed toilet/saxophone/chaingun. Which sort of misses the entire point doesn't it?

All in all what could have been an excellent 2D  hybrid of Borderlands/Metal Slug/Contra became a tired chore of repetition. Maybe the dev team will go on to bigger and better things, I can only hope.

reviewText: This game is SO GOOD. It is like that cool game you heard about but never played. Like you cousin told you about the NES Metal Gear's plot, and you thought it would play like Contra. You also made it look cooler than it ever would on the NES. You made the perfect game a violent 11 year old would want to play in the 90's. Not one a violent 11 year old would make, but one they would play. This game is pretty polished, even though it has a little to much grinding. Also this game really is not like Metal Slug at all, it's like Contra. Sure the art style and sprites are similar, but the game play is more like Contra with slower (not slow) gameplay than Metal Slug. Also despite all the different levels, you will play the same levels with the same robots, and the same backgrounds over and over again. This makes the game loses a lot of its luster long before you can actually finish the game. Some of the ideas are interesting, the hunting, the upgrades to the guns, and the supporting characters. These all have flaws though. The hunting is repetative and gives few real rewards. The upgrades are confusing, with some bullets not working after you change one part of you gun. The supporting charaters are basically just fun one-liner machines, and while I like them they should have more lines, or somethings. Currently they just feel very repetative. That really is the main flaw of the game, how repetative it is.  It should have had a few things cut, or more levels and enemies. It should provide hours of fun though.

reviewText:
If you like Metal Slug- this is WAY better. All the old school charm, but none of the crappy controls. You get to build your own custom guns, upgrade your merc, and they didn't phone in the level content. I'm looking forward to trying the multiplayer.

EDIT: Nevermind. This game is a chore. The gun thing is fine, but there is not as much customization as you might think. Most combinations just make crap guns. In order to use special ammo, you pretty much have to use parts wou may not want or that may take away aspects of the gun you like. I suppose this was done to keep people from making caustic longrang auto shotguns or something. The reload mechanic is alright. I still love the art and the gameplay is tight, but man the boss fights generally suck. Not the challenge or the pattern or the attacks! All that is fine! The problem is that they change locations. You pretty much get the first encounter to defeat them and if you don't smack them completely, in the first go, they flee to another part of the map, immediately spawn (if someone is there or not) and start going through their pattern. By the time you get to the location where they spawned, you get a few prescious seconds to attack them before they flee again. Now, you could leave the game running where they last spawned and eventually they will come back to that location, but that is boreing. So basically, it is a lame dynamic that greatly detracts from the game.

This is not just one boss- but one boss they use over an over again.

Also, the massive amount of levels are mostly repeats. I could have done with a more cogent/crafted set of story driven levels, one leading to the other, or an open world, or a big overworld map, but this constant revisiting of places I just wooped up on and finding them completely repopulated with bosses that flee and hostages and all that . . . jeez. This little war is being severely mismanaged. I understand that he is cloning soldiers and repopulating the levels, but come on! The same levels over and over again? Why not hit the cloning facility ASAP! Cut off supplies to the facility, sabotage the AA guns, drop some mercs in over the wall with that heli (or use a teleporter) and  de-CLAW the general! You have time to think about these things as you are running through a level for the 16th time chasing a coward in a jet.

The fix? Make more of the repeat levels optional and make the bosses only spawn in their next location when a player actually shows up there. That should only require an if/then check to see if a merc is in the battle area! Again, the game could be a lot of fun, but it is a chore, and thus, not fun. The more I play it the more I am disapointed, but I'll eventually finish just becasue I like Paul Robertson's art style and the action is pretty good.

Niche fanbase.

reviewText:
Not a recommendation exactly, but more like my early thoughts on this pre-release game.

Art style is like Metal Slug, which is what drew me in initially. However, it plays more like Mega Man. You have a life bar so you don't have to play perfectly, and there's a little more platforming than a Slug game. No insta-death traps or pits, which is nice. It's got that Gears of War reload action bar; can add tension or be a distraction in the heat of the moment. All around, gameplay's pretty solid if not easy to a Mega Man veteran.

100 stages is misleading; it's really 100 missions spread over a handful of branching-path areas that are reused. You'll see the same zones multiple times. Good for getting familiar with the terrain, but revisiting the same places gets repetitive.

Downed enemies can drop materials that're used for gun/knife/perk crafting. And there's lots of gun parts to craft. Some are interesting, others seem nearly identical stat-wise. Gathering rare mats can kinda suck, but it gives you more to do in-game than just run 'n gun all the time.

Both local and online multiplayer available.  Haven't tried either one, but hear it's good.  When picked up, crafting mats are given to everyone (though the resultant item can be different from player-to-player due to individual perks) so no ninja looting required.

There are bugs that need squashing. They'll be tweaking and adjusting gameplay/menus/UI. There's a lack of challenge for some.  It's missing a compelling reason to keep playing besides a basic story and unlocking new craftables.  But in an unfinished state, it's not bad and will only get better. Can't fully recommend it yet, nor would I discourage anyone to try it out if they like this style of game.  At the very least, it's worth keeping an eye on for the future.

#1 tip: Utilize dat map!!

#2 tip: Magazine size affects your gun's power. Big mags, low damage. Small mags, death machine that needs constant reloading.

reviewText:
As much as I want to recommend this game, I find that I have a very hard time doing so the more I played the game.

I picked it up on sale from the Humble Bundle (So, really, it hurts my heart to write a negative review) because it looks a lot like Contra or Metal Slug, and I played both of those until the bitter end.

What seperates this game from those is that this game is not fast paced nor run and gun. As much as it tries to paint itself out to be run and gun, it simply isn't. Too often you're forced to stop to jump kill an enemy, or wait for 3 or more cycles of a shield trying to kill you while you try and kill it. A vast majority of the enemies are simply slow moving or didn't move at all. I felt like I was grinding the beginnings of an MMO with no story.

Playing this game without a controller is hard and playing full screen hurts my eyes (that's less to do with the game and more the 2D medium.)

The pros are the customizablity that comes with the game. It was an unexpected twist to an old classic.

Sorry Tribute Games, I'm struggling to get past the first 45 minutes, and I doubt I'll give it the play time to see if it gets better. It might be a slow start situation, but with this kind of game, I almost don't want to find out...

reviewText:
This will probably be one of the best games to go completely un-noticed for some time.

Imagine metal slug with beautiful animations and art.  Add to that an absurdly fleshed out weapon crafting and customization set, along with character perks, a quest progression, and online co-op multiplayer.  Enemies, music, art style, everything is done as a love letter to platformer shooters of old, be it metal slug, or mega-man, the game feels like a modernized homage to the genre.

(Encumbrance, Health, Rate of Fire, Damage, Elemental weapon types, Limited inventory system, crafting with dozens of different base materials as well as rare ones for higher end stuff, player skins, time based rewards and 'best' tracking.)

Whoever is doing marketing for this game needs to be beaten with a stick, because their job should be easy as hell.

I'm excited to see what the final version of this game looks like, as I'm already enjoying it a lot. Bear in mind that this game is still absolutely in development, and while I'm sure it looks similar to what the final product will, there are bugs, and missing features etc.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings is a Metal Slug-like with material collection, equipment enhancements, and more specific mission goals other than simply reaching the end of a level and killing a big thing.

Once you get past the issue of setting up a proper controller - which can currently be done by remapping the 360 controller to whatever controller you use in Steam's Big Picture Mode then playing the game in that mode, the game feels very finessed in terms of fine character control and movement becomes fairly fluid.

The graphics are charming, the gameplay is generally fun, though sometimes it can be a little grindy looking for lots of a somewhat rare item to complete your equipment collections.

Overall this game is badass and very much worth the cost. We give this game a FIVE... ...out of five.

reviewText: This game is full of life, challenges, and awesome gameplay. I definitely recommend picking up this game and playing it with a group of friends. With a crisp retro appeal and awesome sound track, Mercenary Kings not only plays good, it feels good. If you're a fan of Metal Slug, Mega Man, or Metroidvania-esque games, you'll definitely enjoy this game.

reviewText: Fans of Metal Slug will feel right at home, though Merc Kings throws a few extras in: the weapon customization between missions allows a wide range of choices between various elemental damage, ammunition types, accuracy, firing rate, range, and  magazine size, letting you decide if it's worth the extra damage to wait out a longer reload time for example. Mission areas are reused to interesting effect, as you'll have different objectives each time you choose a new mission, requiring players to explore areas more fully as you fulfill more objectives. Online multiplayer is a plus, and the sound track is fun to jam along with. Alone or co-op the game is a lot of fun.

This game is a mix between Monster Hunter, Borderlands and Metal Slug. Being mostly Monster Hunter in almost every aspect of the game, Borderlands because of the variety of guns and funny story/boss moments, and lastly Metal Slug being only the art style NOT GAMEPLAY.

Much like Monster Hunter it has:
- lots of collectible materials for crafting
- sense of exploration (you need to find the boss/enemies/items/materials)
- boss fights (you need to know how your adversary's moves)
- boss capture feature (I think there was no need to copy this but its not a bad addition :P)
- campsite resembles monster hunter village in a practical way even hunting grounds is similar to village farm
- food system with buffs
- you are better of prepared for a quest at hand
- unlock-able progression

If you think this is like Metal Slug IT IS NOT its far from it this is a exploration platformer.
So if you like Monster Hunter you will like this game.
A little bit overpriced but if you find a promo its worth it ;)

pros:
- Storry: rich and unpredictable events
- Graphics and art style: verry detailed and funny animations and design
- Gameplay: requires skill and timing to avoid enemies

cons:
- Low replay value: after you finish the game you can cuntinue to upgrade your weapon but there is no point because there are no more missions
- Unscaled multiplayer: all level players join in, meaning that you can randomly join a high level lobby with impossible missions in relation to your level

reviewText:
If you are looking at this, buy this game.

Seriously, if you have interest enough to be looking at this page, I assure you this game will deliver. It will. It just will.

Mercenary Kings is, at its core, a perfect blend of Contra, Metal Slug, and Monster Hunter, all represented with stunningly crafted sprites and an artstyle that is just amazing. The gameplay is satisfying and precise like Contra, from the shooting to the platforming and the controls. On top of that, it has the addictive collecting and crafting of Monster Hunter. You will find yourself unable to stop as you want to collect more items to personalize your character.

The personalization is top notch. Weapon customization is absurdly awesome. There are tons of options to mix and match to create a gun that really fits your play-style, and all of them are very well-balanced. You could spend hours just trying out all of the combinations to see what you like best.

The game is currently in alpha, but it has a level of polish like no other early access game I've seen. It is fully playable with seemingly no bugs in sight. Its truly astonishing - I really feel they could have called the game finished already, but nevertheless they are still cranking out updates for it, so don't let that early access" label scare you off.

All in all
date: I was pleasantly surprised at just how fun this game was. Playing this game has actually gotten me to say "Wow
hoursPlayed: something that not many games can do. I was hoping for some fun
voteText: Contra-styled platforming - and this game did more than deliver."

reviewText:
If you enjoy a healthy dose of dopamins with your friends, this is the game for you. The amount of content this game has is ridiculous. 25 hours in and I'm maybe 2/3 of the way through the missions, and it's just getting harder by the mission, so the last 1/3 is probably gonna take just as long as the rest. Not to mention that you get so many unlocks to buy that you end up redoing missions to get the materials you need for your upgrade. And redoing them to get them on a faster time for extra bonuses, or doing the side objectives.

One thing I'm not such a fan of is the reuse of the same maps. There's just too many missions happening on the same map, some of them are pretty much equal to the previous one. There's also some issues with desyncing on coop, forcing you to remake the server.

Over all though this is sweet game for the price with tons of content. Don't know if I'd recommend it for solo, but it's definitely fun in coop.

reviewText:
I wish I could recommend this game, but I really, really can't.  The controls are sluggish, jumping is floaty and aggravatingly unresponsive, weapons either take too long to kill something or spend too much time reloading, and the entire experience is a slow-moving slog.

The underlying issue with this game is that EVERYTHING is designed to take far too long or is intentionally tedious.  There are many missions with mission timers 25 minutes longer or more, with the goal of just scouring each and every room to find weapon parts.  If this sounds like MMO fetch quests, you're right, and these missions are just as grindy, made even worse by the fact that you will do them on maps where you have ALREADY been through the map 4-5 times already.

Movement speed?  Way too slow, even with light weapons.  Even the firing mode is lousy, giving you a pathetic 4 firing directions instead of the bog-standard 360-degree joystick- or mouse-based method that has been around for decades now.  The view frame is much too zoomed-in, meaning you frequently can't see where you're going, causing you to blunder into enemies or traps, as well as triggering incredibly excessive amounts of off-screen enemy respawns.  Map layouts range from mediocre to aggravating, with a great many paths hanging just over your head that you can't access unless you walk halfway across the map to a ladder or something.

The customizable weapons system SEEMED interesting at first, but it's both poorly balanced and based on grinding out items to get the items to make decent parts.  Machine guns have low damage and high magazines, making dealing with many standard enemies, and especially several bosses that have only limited vulnerability, very tedious.  Shotguns deal huge damage and have low magazines, with their balance" mechanism being semi-auto firing; this means you spend HUGE amounts of time mashing the fire button
date: which is just plain ridiculous when they could have easily just left the shotguns as full-auto weapons for the simple sake of ENJOYMENT.  On top of that

hoursPlayed: but have minimal performance differences.  And even the bullet types are blocked off by forcing you to have the right level of compatibility with your current weapon parts

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game - the pixel art (from Paul Robertson of Scott Pilgrim fame) is excellent, and the game looks like a Metal Slug/Contra type thing. In reality the game is pretty open, dropping you a large map with no guidance where to go. The missions are often fetch quests, leaving you to, completly at random, stumble upon whatever it is you're required to find. The in game map doesn't record where you've been, or where objectives are.

Addded to this unfocussed gameplay, is the odd addition of Gears of War style 'active reload', which is just an annoyance, surprisingly bland and forgettable music, and a needlessly complex weapon upgrade system.

It all just feels like a bit of a mess, and is simply dull to play. It's a real shame.
voteText: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings was one of the most disappointing games I've played in a while.  It looks great and the premise gives off the vibe that it's going to play like a Metal Slug, Contra or any other fast-paced 2D action shooter.  It doesn't and almost every aspect of the gameplay is poor.

You'll notice immediately the intentional jump delay.  I don't know why the devs were so tied into this mechanic, it's terrible in this type of game.  You can get away with deliberate jumping in some titles, but not this one.  The jump delay makes the game feel so off.  MK also has reloading.  Why?  I don't know and having to reload constantly brings nothing positive to the game.  There's also the issue that you have to press down to pick up items, and you'll have to pick up items constantly and it breaks any flow the game manages to create.  I wish the whole crafting angle wasn't even a thing because it doesn't appeal to me in the least and from I've read, it's not any good even if you're into crafting.

Supposedly the game is super repetitive and grindy as well, but I didn't last long enough to find out.  If you're looking for some fasted-paced 2D shooting action on PC, you're much better off with the Metal Slug ports, even though DotEmu didn't exactly do a great job on them.

reviewText: When I first played this game I was definitely not a fan, but later I came back to it and really tried to get into it. I play with the keyboard and don't like the controls, they don't feel natural and so I really had to get used to them. The missions are not very challenging more so annoying if anything. You just go around the map and have to collect a certain number of this or kill a certain number of that. The maps themselves are the same ones over and over again, there are maybe three different maps in total. The game gets really repetitive at least for me. One good thing though is that you have a lot of missions, I've played for about 6 hours and still haven't completed all the recruit missions and that is just the start. I really like how you can craft weapons with the materials you pick up, allowing you to make some pretty awesome and overpowered guns. The knives aren't worth buying, they don't give you much more damage than the one you start out with, and you will be using your gun for the majority of the time anyways since there is no limit to bullets, you just have to reload. All in all the game is pretty mediocre, it's pretty fun for the first couple of hours but gets boring quite quickly and I can't help feeling like I could be spending my time playing something more enjoyable.

reviewText: So, there's been a bit of hate against this game in some other reviews but I would argue that this is a top notch game. I have only played 2.5 hours so far but I enjoy the way the game is structred, the art style and the tight controls. It is a neat amalgam of arcade-style platforming shmup mixed with level-fiddling RPG.\n\nThe complaints I have heard say the game gets too repetitive and boring. The time I have already put in more than justifies the purchase in my opinion and I haven't once felt it's been repetitive. More importantly, I think the online co-op works wonderfully. My friend and I have enjoyed playing and strategizing through missions using Steam's voice chat. It works great if you're catching up with a bud and playing some games while at it.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings is too old school for my taste. It's one of the games I regret buying because I didn't enjoy it in the slightest. The graphics are wonderful, mind you, but the gameplay is like the old action platformers from the 90's, mixed up with some modern features, like crafting and tons of (repetitive) missions. The fact that there are timers in it didn't help either because it forces you to speed things up and in the process get yourself killed. Get yourself killed enough and it's mission over and you have to restart entirely from the beginning. I had no fun playing this and I probably never will, unless they change things up in the future.
It's not a bad game per se, but it's just not my taste anymore. If you still like these sorts of games I'm sure you'll have a blast.

[Rating: 63/100]

reviewText:
Things I enjoyed: Artwork is fantastic (If you're into pixel graphics), music was engaging, and the bosses were pretty cool.
The knife mechanics are interesting, the ability to deflect bullets with your knife certainly makes the game easier. I enjoyed the different load outs I could make with a gun, and the different ammunitions associated with them. I think I'll always love hot hearts.

Definitely not Metal Slug, though.

Things I didn't enjoy: wanting to build a particular gun, only to realize I need to craft it using materials I have to keep finding throughout the game. In that sense, the grinding gets pretty boring. However, the use of achievements (like speed running the levels) make the grinding arbitrarily less annoying.
Personally, the use of a good gun renders the knife not very useful in situations.

reviewText: Fantastic sprite art from Paul Robertson makes this game a joy to play. It's an interesting mix of resource gathering and challenging action. The only thing I dislike from the game is the way local co-op works with it's awkwardly small splitscreen gameplay where it divides the screen into four, even with two players. Still, I had an immensely good time with the game, and it feels almost like the natural evolution of 8 and 16-bit gaming had the 3D era never happened.

reviewText:
Everyone making Metal Slug comparisons and judging it on those grounds went into this with the wrong expectations. Neither the steam page nor any gameplay video, now or prior to its full release, ever promoted this game as being similar to Metal Slug.

With that out of the way, let's come out and say what it is: this is Mega Man x Monster Hunter. The controls, level design, enemies, and gameplay are all explicitly cribbed from Mega Man, while the mission design, gear crafting progression, and boss mechanics are lifted from Monster Hunter. You accept a mission, from something as mundane as killing a couple mooks, to hunting two of a particular boss, and you're dropped into the level with the supplies you've brought with you. Certain supplies can be gathered in the field, as can materials, and you traverse the rather sizable level completing your objective, after which you return to base, where you resupply, craft guns, knives, and skills, and select a new mission. Much like Monster Hunter, this game encourages cooperative play, so rev up the online or bring along a friend, or you're quickly going to find yourself frustrated by how long later missions take to complete.

If that sounds at all appealing to you, by all means, pick it up. You could easily squeeze at least 20 hours out of it, and it's an excellent couch co-op title.

reviewText:
The Good:

- I grew up playing NES and SNES platformers, and so I truly enjoy seeing this art style popularized again. For what Mercenary Kings offers in terms of gameplay, the art style matches up nicely and makes the game feel cohesive.

- Mercenary Kings offers a plethora of weapon customization options. The abundance of options enticed me to spend hours mixing and matching parts across different weapon categories in order to perfect a gun suited to my specific play style.

- Surprisingly, the game has a entertaining story with multiple twists. Mercenary Kings was definitely improved by this because it justified playing through the absurd amount of story missions (112 unique missions in total) in order to reach the conclusion.

The Bad:

- I loathed how Mercenary Kings portrayed their women antagonists and protagonists. The overt objectification only served to reflect that the designers are out of touch with where modern audiences are in terms of gender relations.

- The mission structures, goals, and levels in Mercenary Kings are extremely repetitive. While the goal might change between missions, you’re frequently placed in the same level to achieve this objective. Additionally, the objectives also lacked diversity - for example, often you’re collecting an object, neutralizing an enemy, or capturing a specific enemy.  Unquestionably, the central problem of Mercenary Kings is quantity over quality.

In order to acquire the necessary number of parts to construct banners, ornaments, gun parts, knife parts, and mods you’ll have to grind far too much.

Final Verdict:
Mercenary Kings looks like a Metal Slug clone (this is actually the reason I bought it without first researching the game), but it is far from that. The gameplay is much slower, and the RPG elements take center stage as opposed to a straightforward shoot ‘em up action adventure. I can’t recommend this game at full price. I purchased this game for 1.00 (humblebundle), and I had fun, but after the first ten to twenty hours it became an endeavor to simply complete the game. However, because of what I paid, I didn’t feel cheated.

6/10.

reviewText: Played through the game beginning to end 2-player.  Can safely say it is a great multiplayer game with some actual balance between all the kinds of guns you can make.  Challenging platforming action, hilarious writing, and cartoony graphics are all in this quality package.\n\nHowever, beware the way multiplayer is handled.  Enemies seemed to spawn based on the host player's location, so as a guest in the game, enemies would oftentimes appear out of nowhere or teleport around the area, resulting in free hits.  Still worth it.

reviewText:
Here is my Mercenaray Kings Review in 30Seconds

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i5xRbPQzRl0

When you base your game’s aesthetics on Metal Slug, it’s easy to make a good looking game. What’s harder is to give it a twist that makes it a game of it’s own. In Mercenary Kings you craft weapons, armor and mods with loot you pick off of enemies. This is not just for giggles though, the game is hard and you need to craft your own chance at winning.

Playing as a team of up to four is a lot of fun, but the scenery is repetitive and even annoying when you are trying to kill a boss and he runs off into another part of the map.

Awesome art and funny dialogue in a somewhat monotonous gameplay. But it is still in development, so it has a lot of potential.

7 slugs out of 10.

reviewText:
134 hours and still going strong.

Now look, not everyone enjoys this game and I get it, but I can't understand these people who played the games for less than an hour who give it a negative review.

I've played this game for how long I have because of a few factors.

1. It's fun for me. That doesn't mean it is for everyone else.
2. Great style and music.
3. Great replayability for speed purposes.
and finally,
4. Alpha is the best boss ever no questions asked.

I've completed this game numerous times while speedrunning and currently hold the fastest time for completing the game from start to finish. This game can be frustrating at times when you're doing this but to be completely honest, if you take your time through this game you'll find it to be fairly easy.

Take these reviews with a grain of salt as always because nobody can really tell you what YOU will experience while playing this game. This is just my opinion in a sea of others.

reviewText: I would say this game is a good pick up for people who like challenging game experiences that ask you to grind a bit. In my opinion this title is best described as a mix of Mega Man and Monster Hunters all while being skinned to have the appearance of Metal Slug. If you don't have a friend(s) to play this with the missions can definitely seem less fun and  more drawn out as you will have to do all aspects of a mission by yourself. Even with that being said, you will probably still feel like a savage when you have killed two bosses, saved all the hostages, and set a new fastest time all in a single solo mission. Nontheless, having competent team mates is awesome and the most fun experience as the multiplayer is where this game truly shines. Mainly because of the fact you can split up to wreck missions more aggressively and faster since you will be able to cover the various terrains more strategically, and more efficiently overall. Like they say, four brains is better than one" lol.\n\nMy only true gripe with this game is its lack of controller configuration. I personally play this game  on a Fightstick (arcade styled joystick). So while my controller worked right out of the gate the button layout was all wrong. JoytoKey and Xpadder would usually fix a problem like this
date: but for this game it doesn't. The game will just continue to read the controller inputs and the keyboard inputs at the same time which will make you have binded actions you literally don't want. To fix this I actually had to go into the .CFG file this game made for my controller and switch around the button ID which took forever to figure out
recommended: This should be fixed honestly! Tribute Games just let us configure our buttons properly not just our keyboards please. Also
hoursPlayed: since I dont have a "right stick"  on my controller of choice I can't scroll the map either lmao. Another way to scroll the map would be nice too.\n\nEven with the controller and map issue I am having. I still have a blast running and gunning destroying everything in site

reviewText:
this game is amazing. played it co-op. the last couple bosses are super-hard, though.

the weapon system can be hard to understand. sometimes, the effects of a weapon are not explained, and you will not discover them until you equip them. or sometimes you need a combination of parts to get an effect, even though nothing on-screen tells you this; you discover it on accident. or never do, and get disappointed that you can't seem to make an automatic weapon even though the weapon description says it's automatic.

still, despite my paragraph of rambling, this is a small complaint. the game is HUGE fun; getting new weapon parts is exciting; killing bosses is rewarding; the music and graphics are great.

don't be turned off after you realize you've been playing different parts of the same map for 10 missions now. you get a new map every time you advance in rank. the maps get HUGE and complicated and intricate. it's possible the designers baby new players a little too long, worried a big map would be too scary. but it's only a LITTLE too long :)

reviewText:
To me, this game is mostly comparable to a megaman game, with grinding.
The art is awesome and the gameplay is pretty tight, though a bit clunky at times.
The boss battles are also very fun.
I would recommend this if you like older games like those on the SNES.

Some down-sides are:
- If you want to do all the missions (why wouldn't you), you'll have to revisit the same levels a lot of times.
- The enemy respawns happen a bit to fast
- Sometimes I feel like the level design forces me to takes hits
- The weapon customization is cool and all, but maybe there are a bit too many options?

reviewText: Fantastic sprite art from Paul Robertson makes this game a joy to play. It's an interesting mix of resource gathering and challenging action. The only thing I dislike from the game is the way local co-op works with it's awkwardly small splitscreen gameplay where it divides the screen into four, even with two players. reviewText:
Everyone making Metal Slug comparisons and judging it on those grounds went into this with the wrong expectations. Neither the steam page nor any gameplay video, now or prior to its full release, ever promoted this game as being similar to Metal Slug.

With that out of the way, let's come out and say what it is: this is Mega Man x Monster Hunter. The controls, level design, enemies, and gameplay are all explicitly cribbed from Mega Man, while the mission design, gear crafting progression, and boss mechanics are lifted from Monster Hunter. You accept a mission, from something as mundane as killing a couple mooks, to hunting two of a particular boss, and you're dropped into the level with the supplies you've brought with you. Certain supplies can be gathered in the field, as can materials, and you traverse the rather sizable level completing your objective, after which you return to base, where you resupply, craft guns, knives, and skills, and select a new mission. Much like Monster Hunter, this game encourages cooperative play, so rev up the online or bring along a friend, or you're quickly going to find yourself frustrated by how long later missions take to complete.

If that sounds at all appealing to you, by all means, pick it up. You could easily squeeze at least 20 hours out of it, and it's an excellent couch co-op title.

reviewText: A fun romp through side-scrolling shooty action. The game plays very similarly to Metal Slug and games of that nature but with a bit more forgiveness. Gameplay's pretty standard and fun without too much innovation in terms of controls and whatnot but what keeps it interesting is the customizable weapons. You completely customize your loadout with 6 different weapon parts at any given time that have different stats that affect how your character plays. Will you take a handgun with only 2 parts and be super fast and agile but with limited firepower? Will you take a huge minigun with tons of ammo that pierces walls and completely destroys things before it gets on screen with the side-effects of moving slower than a slug in molasses? The entire game revolves around finding loot to craft new weapons and mods that change how you play your character. It works extremely well because of the focus that it has on variety and uniqueness to each weapon. It's not perfectly balanced yet but it's still in development so it's not an issue. An excellent game that really gets the visceral fun of just raining bullets down pat.

reviewText: Metal Slug meets Monster Hunter with a dash of Borderlands. A very fun shoot-em-up that pays homage to the Metal Slug franchise while making some unique innovations, the biggest one being it's detailed weapon-crafting system. You can find resources during missions, use them to create new gun parts, then customize your gun in any way you choose! The difficulty curve of the missions also scales rather well, providing a decent challenge for players as they progress. The retro graphics are quite enjoyable and nostalgic, with Tribute Games having enlisted Paul Robertson, the mind behind the design of Scott Pilgrim vs. The World: The Game, Pirate Baby's Cabana Street Fight 2006, and Kings of Power 4 Billion%, to help with the art style, sprites, and animation. Multiplayer makes this game much more fun, with both online and local co-op, so you can take down the terrorists of C.L.A.W. with your friends! Definitely worth the buy!

reviewText:
A side scrolling shooter with a modern graphic style of metal slug. The murmurs of the game being grindy and tedious are unfortunately true. The game is mission based. You pick a mission from your starting camp and load into the area to complete the mission. All missions are quite repetitive as they are either; save hostage(s), find and talk to npc, gather resources, find and kill/capture character. It didn't take me long before becoming bored at the tasks i was given.

All the areas are for the most part the same with the exception of where certain objectives are placed. Typically the areas took upon the same variation of an industrial warehouse.

There is customizing in the form of guns. This is the most interesting aspect of the game. You can rearrange an assortment of gun parts together to create some rather amusing but effective guns. Although acquiring new gun parts requires you to finish a chapter of missions. These missions again are chore to go through as it seems you're constantly doing the same thing.

There is crafting which consists of gun parts, passive perks you can wear, and a few other items. To craft you gather resources dropped by enemies or found in crates along the progress of your mission.

Other than the graphic style and gun customization there isn't much else to this game. The areas are bland and lacking variety. The missions are highly repetitive, laborious, and uninspired. I had fun initially, but quickly noticed the flaws that became harder to overlook and enjoy the game. I would only advise those interested to purchase on a sale.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
My unfortunate first negative review on steam.  Bought this game with the intentions of playing with a friend, but even from the get-go (And all the way up till the end boss) I had nagging issues that continued to hamper my experience with the game.

The foremost offender is the incredibly awkward controlling.  Characters react based on how heavy their weapons are, but even with light equipment, jumps can be incredibly pixel percise with a slow reaction to pressing the jump button.   This becomes incredibly annoying on bosses that rush from side to side on the screen, and you think you press the button early enough only to have the wind up time keep you from clearing your foe.  Aiming can also be an issue when trying to shoot smaller enemies that move through the air (Not to mention chase you after the camera changes and moves them off screen), theres no way to shoot diagonally which means you'll have to constantly run under vertical enemies to hit them or lead them into your shots.

As you get further in, you notice that the mission strcutres all fall into the same few catagories:  Find stuff or kill/capture stuff.  It becomes more tedious in the latter half of the game as the levels expand, leaving you and your friend(s) to traverse large boring structures with occasionally respawning enemies that even with high health and defense items, can still tear away large portions of your health.  And with limited carrying space for items, trying to heal in our outside the hospital zones can be incredibly tedious as there's no ingame way to speed up the hospital healing process.  I suppose thats why most missions have extra long times (Anywhere between 15-30 minutes usually), but it just bogs down the experience.  The bosses are far to repetitive too, having to face the same lot multiple times across the games ranked missions and an occaisonal unique boss at the end of most ranks.

The weapon crafting is an excercise in patience, having to always constantly change out one gun trait for another, taking time in order to get anywhere close to a satisfying weapon.  More so, since the crafting system relies on the materials you find in the stage, you may be forced to run back into earlier levels and hope that enemies respawn AND drop the items you're looking for.

If I'm pressed to say anything positive about it, the presentation has a nice psuedo-Metal Slug/SNK feel thats still unique enough to be a full rip off, and the music often catchy.  But thats not enough to get a recommendation here, its just not fleshed out enough to be fun either by yourself or with friends.

reviewText:
The Good:

- I grew up playing NES and SNES platformers, and so I truly enjoy seeing this art style popularized again. For what Mercenary Kings offers in terms of gameplay, the art style matches up nicely and makes the game feel cohesive.

- Mercenary Kings offers a plethora of weapon customization options. The abundance of options enticed me to spend hours mixing and matching parts across different weapon categories in order to perfect a gun suited to my specific play style.

- Surprisingly, the game has a entertaining story with multiple twists. Mercenary Kings was definitely improved by this because it justified playing through the absurd amount of story missions (112 unique missions in total) in order to reach the conclusion.

The Bad:

- I loathed how Mercenary Kings portrayed their women antagonists and protagonists. The overt objectification only served to reflect that the designers are out of touch with where modern audiences are in terms of gender relations.

- The mission structures, goals, and levels in Mercenary Kings are extremely repetitive. While the goal might change between missions, you’re frequently placed in the same level to achieve this objective. Additionally, the objectives also lacked diversity - for example, often you’re collecting an object, neutralizing an enemy, or capturing a specific enemy.  Unquestionably, the central problem of Mercenary Kings is quantity over quality.

In order to acquire the necessary number of parts to construct banners, ornaments, gun parts, knife parts, and mods you’ll have to grind far too much.

Final Verdict:
Mercenary Kings looks like a Metal Slug clone (this is actually the reason I bought it without first researching the game), but it is far from that. The gameplay is much slower, and the RPG elements take center stage as opposed to a straightforward shoot ‘em up action adventure. I can’t recommend this game at full price. I purchased this game for 1.00 (humblebundle), and I had fun, but after the first ten to twenty hours it became an endeavor to simply complete the game. However, because of what I paid, I didn’t feel cheated.

6/10.

reviewText:
Here is my Mercenaray Kings Review in 30Seconds

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i5xRbPQzRl0

When you base your game’s aesthetics on Metal Slug, it’s easy to make a good looking game. What’s harder is to give it a twist that makes it a game of it’s own. In Mercenary Kings you craft weapons, armor and mods with loot you pick off of enemies. This is not just for giggles though, the game is hard and you need to craft your own chance at winning.

Playing as a team of up to four is a lot of fun, but the scenery is repetitive and even annoying when you are trying to kill a boss and he runs off into another part of the map.

Awesome art and funny dialogue in a somewhat monotonous gameplay. But it is still in development, so it has a lot of potential.

7 slugs out of 10.

reviewText:
134 hours and still going strong.

Now look, not everyone enjoys this game and I get it, but I can't understand these people who played the games for less than an hour who give it a negative review.

I've played this game for how long I have because of a few factors.

1. It's fun for me. That doesn't mean it is for everyone else.
2. Great style and music.
3. Great replayability for speed purposes.
and finally,
4. Alpha is the best boss ever no questions asked.

I've completed this game numerous times while speedrunning and currently hold the fastest time for completing the game from start to finish. This game can be frustrating at times when you're doing this but to be completely honest, if you take your time through this game you'll find it to be fairly easy.

Take these reviews with a grain of salt as always because nobody can really tell you what YOU will experience while playing this game. This is just my opinion in a sea of others.

reviewText: S'pretty fun for a while, but after a point the grind just got to be too much for me. I don't mind grinding, and actually enjoy it in a lot of games, but make grinding faster, more convenient, easier, and fun. Not slow, hard, boring, tedious and mind numbingly repetitive. I'm going to give this a no, but if I could I would simply give this a neutral vote or both, and if you can stand the grind then it's quite a lot of fun I feel, and would highly recommend it to those with sufficient patience to enjoy this game. I'm only giving this a no cause I personally couldn't stand the grinding. Honestly, my biggest problem with this game is that some materials are just way too hard to get in any kind of significant quantities. To get around this problem I suggest having higher tier enemies drop rarer materials instead of the common materials I already have literally hundreds of that all the lower tier enemies already drop. Also, the netcode could use improvement. At the moment it's kinda not very good.

reviewText:
This is a 2d Platform Indie Arcade Side Scrolling Shoot 'm Up

Soldiers.... MOVE OUT !!!!

Background Info:
-----------------------

Genre: Action / Platformer

Fun Game, Online Co-op, If cheap give it a try !!
I give it a 7/10 score.

reviewText:
Mercenary kings is a 2D Side-scroller Coop shooter, That you can play with 4 players either Locally (Split-screen) or online with friends or public ( random people ).
The game can be thought of as mega man meats metal slug, but it is not fast like them , the movement and all is a bit slower but not in a bad way , it just suits the game completely.
The game is very challenging not your average ( Carry 1 gun kill them all ) game , it requires precision and skills and speed.

It has a big set of weapons that you keep crafting , and unlocking new Craft-able weapons as you unlock more missions.
Adding extra effects to weapons such as ( fire , ice..etc ), giving the weapon more ammo , increasing damage or decreasing damage and adding accuracy increasing range and much more, hell ... even knives you can change them.

The missions , You start as a Recruit , around 20 missions or so , and once all finished you get promoted to Private .. and another big set of new missions , and so on and so on , as you go further the game gets harder and harder
Missions Are Capture, Gather, Neutralize , Rescue, And many more.

The enemies are pretty well designed, They are tough , gets tougher the more you play and new enemies.

Level design is great, you can look at the graphics and characters at the screenshots the design is just too good, Also the animations are perfect the story is good ( Nothing you wouldn't expect ) And with a hint of comedy in it.

Purchase items , or equip mods or upgrade your armor as you play to become stronger and to follow with the game's progress.

So coming to sum up this beautiful game.

PROS :
1 - Great level/characters Design , with good soundtracks that gives you the rush to play.
2 - Huge set of customize-able weapons and mods , equipment and mods, and customize-able characters.
3 - Challenging gameplay , requires teamwork ( if you're playing coop ).
4 - Big set of missions and extra optional objectives and secret objectives ( for you to find out )
5 - Your Typical bad guy (Claw) clan and you are the good guys to stop them.
6 - Great animations and gameplay, that mixes both action and comedy to keep it interesting.

Cons :
1 - .. the community expected so much of this game and wanted it to be something its not so they got disappointed.
notice this con is not in the game itself , i LOVE this game but the community needs to learn not to do what they did now ... i feel sad that the front page is filled with negative reviews.


Reasons why it has those negative reviews.
1 - The players Set a standard and got disappointed , its their own fault you should never expect a game to be something because when its released even if its good but not to your standards you will hate it.
2 - They wanted the game to be a Metal slug/Mega man Badass Fast paced action shooter but online , So just saying basically they wanted it to be Metal Slug 4 player Online coop With Customize-able weapons and all the things this game have but they got disappointed because this game is not like metal slug , but the game is good
3 - They got bored with all the grinding you need to do to craft weapons , Truth be told ? aren't all games with craft-able weapons like that ? I mean in this game you do not really need to grind , you just get the materials while doing the main mission.



So this game is really good, i would not suggest you to buy it if you wanna play it alone, it can be done yeah if you love to solo your games you might enjoy it, but playing with friends is much more fun, Note that playing alone and multi has the same missions so there is no ( Omg the game is impossible to do it alone ).

The average of players playing this each day is 250-270 , so if you have no friends who owns this you might be able to find some random steam players , or go to forum to set a game up

So far i have not encountered any bugs or anything wrong with the game , my friends and i enjoy it so much , and we have some (Offline local-coop) game time, so steam only shows 4 hours but i think we have around 7 hours on it.

IF i found any bugs i will update the review


TL;DR
Such a great 2d shooter game to play with friends
hoursPlayed: and hard and fun missions to keep you and your friends entertained"\n\n10/10

reviewText: Mercenary Kings is a cynical college art project masquerading as a videogame. In less than an hour of playtime, the game managed to show every possible hint of amatuerism in its design. A design based on games from decades ago that had better control schemes.\n\nThe biggest flaw with this game" is the incredibly poor design decisions. The first mistake was the addition of reload for what should have been a relatively simple run-and-gun experience. It breaks the flow of gameplay and often just leaves you huddling behind some barrels until you've reloaded. Not that taking cover matters; The enemies barely move and the barrels are always taller than you are
date: so you have to jump into enemy fire anyway. This is compounded by absolutely byzantine level design that makes backtracking endless and goals impossible. It doesn't help that enemies respawn faster than this game being pushed out the door. On top of that
recommended: the game often imposes time limits on your escapades. The result is endlessly frustrating. The "developers" clearly haven't taken much notice in the games they were so intent on emulating: You can't shoot diagonally. Even Contra
hoursPlayed: a game released in the late '80s
voteText: allowed the player to shoot diagonally. There's no reason this could not have been done here.\n\nMercenary Kings is so bad I thought it was an Early Access title because it has no features and is overpriced. It looks like someone took a game with one level and no interesting game mechanics

reviewText:
The only thing good about this game is the art.

Boring repetitive game play traversing the same map over and over for multiple missions killing the same enemies that reappear in the same spots. A crafting system that doesn't give much of an opportunity to experiment or preview weapon builds before spending your resources and too many stats to compare, very little incentive to really use different types of weapons or ammunition when caustic bullets pretty much handle everything. Reload mechanic is frustrating and disrupts the flow of the game, game does not pause when your viewing the map leaving you vulnerable to the reappearing enemies that may lurk off screen. Retrieving items from your backpack is slow and also disrupts game play you should really be able to toggle through items with a single button click rather than having to hold down a button then navigating a menu and then select your item, you also have go through your backpack to get the walkie talkie out just to call someone so you can leave a mission so many clicks for such a simple thing.

I wanted to like this game but I just couldn't get over the frustrating gameplay mechanics. The comparisons to Metal Slug make no sense this is nothing like Metal Slug not even close, If you wanna play a fast pace action platformer play Metal Slug if you want something slow, repetitive, and grindy play this game.

reviewText: Mercenary Kings is a bad game, it has terrible and awkward controls (even after remapping them) and suffers from very bad gameplay. The main point of the game is to fire your weapon, but wait you cannot fire your weapon up or down while moving nor can you fire diagonally. The enemies also respawn once they leave your screen which is really annoying when you're trying to explore the map. When you die, you don't respawn near your death location instead you're teleported back to the last respawn tent you passed and you have to fight your way back through all the enemies that respawned. Lastly, the game becomes extremely boring and grindy due to the level/rank progression system which forces you to repeat levels over and over until you are able to unlock the next rank's missions.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of having fun, this the game for you. Whether solo or co-op, this game hits on all cylinders and keeps you wanting more and more until its 4 A.M. and you have to go to work in a couple of hours.

The pixel art will leave you breathless (Same guys who did Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World: The Game, if you're familliar!), and is very reminiscent of the Metal Slug series, in more ways than one. The controls are airtight and if you keep dying over and over,  you have no one to blame but yourself, and the jerk who put you down.

The co-op is fantastic, and makes the game so much more enjoyable and lessens the burden of some of the more punishing levels, so if you have a friend to play with, do so!

The gun part collecting is where the game truly shines though, every little mod added or taken away can either turn that ordinary shotgun into a fire breathing dragon, or break it so even your knives seem like a more viable option. (Sometimes, they are!)

Do yourself a favor, pick up this platforming shooter today, and take the fight to CLAW. They need to be taken down.

MOVE OUT!

reviewText:
Okay. Now to be honest, I haven't gone through the entire game as yet. But I figure that I've logged in enough game time on it to give some first impressions.

Admittedly, what initially drew me to this game was the design itself. It was like Contra meets Scott Pilgrim-- similarly designed sprites, chiptune music and such... so it was something of a guilty pleasure.

As a run-and-gun game, there's nothing TOO exceptional about it. The levels are fairly linear, even though there are plenty of nooks and crannies to explore. The story line is okay, though the characters are amusing enough that the plot doesn't plod on.

The real challenge lies in trying to master the levels. Not just in the speed-runs, but also with the secret objectives. Things to help you earn the extra scratch and materials to forge new items to not only make the missions more interesting, but to also unlock hidden perks to get through some of the harder missions.

Missions are basic in nature, but can vary in difficulty due to time constraints and game AI. And the game AI is basic enough to make taking enemies out both easy and frustrating at the same time. There's also the reload feature, which can boost damage, but requires you to pay enough attention to be a distraction at times.

All in all, this is still a fun little run-and-gun, and definitely worth the look when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Yes, Yes, Yes and more YES!

I found about this game through my brother when I went to his house and we wanted a fun multiplayer game, he got this as part of a bundle and had never played it, thought it would be terrible, anyway we give it a go and loved it!

Brilliant old style side scroller platform game, with fun additions such as being able to craft weapons, upgrade aromor with items you collect along the way etc.

An added bonus feature of playing multiplayer on this game, which many others like it do not have, is the fact that you play on your own little screen rather than having to stay in the same area as the other player(s) meaning if there's a split in the road you can each go one way fulfilling the objective quicker or finding more secrets.

The only downside I would comment on is the landscape of the levels is pretty much the same as the last mostly but that doesn't ruin the fun as the objectives change.


Would highly recommend as a fun little multiplayer game.

reviewText:
I saw this game on Steam while back, I looked at the screenshots, and just scoff away.

From screenshots, this game didn't look too much different than the old title: Metal Slug series.

But somehow, I decided to give the video preview a shot, which I normally wouldn't, unless I was initally interested in the game, and about 85% intended to buy it anyways.

After viewing the video, my mind was blown. This game was nothing like Metal Slug, except it's also a 2D side scroller. But this game brought me back memories, it felt more like the old school Megaman, rather than anything else. But best part? Customizations, that's what made this game even better.

The personalizations, the mix and match weapons. Even to character boosts!
Obviously there are a few more things I can see that it can be improved on, and wouldn't hurt to have some voice acting for the dialog lines. But all in all, I'm giving this game a 8 / 10.

I am regretting that I didn't be part of the kickstarter. This game deserves so much more.

reviewText:
Alright, so this is colored two ways. One side is from me and one is from a 4 year old kid.

Me, I think this game is brilliant. I love that there's no forced screen share. I can go do my own thing while my team mate secures other objectives. The art is amazing and the story is interesting and fun. The crafting system brings a new depth to this sort of console side scroller and I appreciate that. Being able to choose missions is great. Not a huge fan of my partner dying x number of times and mission failed. I was a glob darm rock star. I also played this split screen on a 36 HD monitor and thought it was a little too little....a single group map would be fine or no map below would be even better.....I play 10 days on Don't Starve before I start thinking "maybe I need a map..."

Kid thinks it's crazy fun too. His big complaint is "these bad guys keep beating me
date: are you kidding me?" I personally like the challange but he'd like a throw back to the time when a screen is shared and the hardcore gamer in the group blasts the faces and he passes out the heals (he's a good TF2 medic and a good collector of crafting items....he also got me out of a few hairy situations where I was reloading and thinking I was about to die). He likes Metal Slug more.\n\nOverall a very positive experience and I look forward to playing more. So does he
recommended: he cried his eyes out when I told him it was time to stop playing and go home. Great game
hoursPlayed: hope there's some cheap DLC or a modders tool-kit around the corner.\n\nHap Hollys"

reviewText:
The gameplay is basic but fun. The graphics are pixelated but pretty. The music is 8-bit but rockin'. I love this game.

I grew up with the SNES. For you young whipper snappers, that used to be the console of choice before your beloved Playstation and Xbox - back in the glory days of Nintento, before they gave humourous titles to their consoles t

This game plays and feels EXACTLY like an old SNES game, and so I cannot help but feel a sense of nostalgic awesomeness when I play this game, even though it is a brand new 21st century release.

Don't expect any new fangled next-gen additons to this game though:
- Voices? Nope.
- Memorable characters? Nope.
- A nail-biting storyline? Nope.
- Easy mode? Nope.
- Changeable video settings? Nope.

And I wouldn't have it any other way.

Of the 174 games on my steam library, this is in my top 10.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings or the revival of a long forgotten genre!
To make a long storry short Mercenray Kings is what i expect from a good 2D-Platformer. A good Gameplay, a decent storry and a good Soundtrack (even if it sounds like  16bit).

First things first: If you want a High-End 3D-Shoother you´re ABSOLUTELY not looking for this game.
BUT: If you enjoy playing 2-D Platformers (like the famous Megaman games or the early Castlevania games on the NES or SNES)  you´ll definitely have a lot of fun with Mercenary Kings.

The graphics look a little like the games back in the good old times of the SNES. But thanks since these times have passed its looks are more smooth and less edgy. The designers put a lot of time and thought into creating the levels and models.  8/10

The storry itself has no big twists  and unforseen turns but the Characters are designed with a lot of love. 8/10

The gameplay is simple and easy to learn (what´s not so surpising since we talk about a Platformer^^)
A nice idea that sure keeps you going is the almost infinite gunsmithing possibilities. Every part you equip can change how you move and shoot. It takes about 15-20 hours to beat the game (15 if you rush through the game, 20 if you take care of all the small sidequest that alsmot every mission has). 10/10

The soundtrack is as retro as the looks of this game and therefor a perfect match. No fancy orchestral sound, no incredible guitarr riffs but still an enjoyable and throughout the whole game well matched music. 7/10

One of the greates features of this game is the co-op mode where up to 4 players can join the fight.
It never gets old to play a game like that with your friends ;)

Overall Rating, 8.5/10

reviewText:
Think of this game as Metal Slug, but MUCH deeper.  It's got a quest system with goals for every mission you do, including secret goals.  You've got an absolute ♥♥♥♥-ton of things to buy to upgrade your character.  You've got multiple different parts for your gun to interchange.  Stuff like a barrel, magazine, stock, etc.  You can have anything from a lightning sniper rifle to a fire submachine gun and everything in between, even being able to tweak how many bullets and your overall damage.  You've got a knife that you can also have many different versions of.  Useable items like first-aid kits, grenades, c4 to open some doors.

If you're a person who wants to get everything, buckle up.  It's going to take you an awful long time to afford everything.  Every mission is timed, which is a bit annoying at first.  Especially when you haven't had a chance to familiarize yourself with a particular map.  It's probably the biggest drawback to the game if you don't like being rushed.  You'll normally have plenty of time, but some missions don't give you much room to breathe.

Luckily, there's co-op to help you through some of the tougher missions.  You and up to 3 other people can join in the fun.  Tons of bosses, tons of quests, tons of guns.  It's how Metal Slug should've been designed in the first place.
